revision.text:
{{Infobox basketball game | game_name = 2014 Philippine Basketball Marathon | image = [[File:Basketballmarathon2014.png|250px]] | visitor = Bounce Back | home = '''Walang Iwanan''' | visitor_total = 16,783 | home_total = 16,732 | visitor_per1 = | visitor_per2 = | visitor_per3 = | visitor_per4 = | visitor_OT = | visitor_OT2 = | visitor_OT3 = | home_per1 = | home_per2 = | home_per3 = | home_per4 = | home_OT = | home_OT2 = | home_OT3 = | date = 24–29 March 2014 | referee = 40 referees{{cite news|title=Players dig in for long haul as PH bid to set basketball marathon world record underway|url=http://www.spin.ph/sports/basketball/news/players-dig-in-for-long-haul-as-ph-bid-to-set-basketball-marathon-world-record-underway|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=Sports Interactive Network Philippines|date=24 March 2014}} | arena = Meralco Gym | city = [[Pasig]] | team1coach = Johnedel Cardel (Walang Iwanan) | team2coach = Louie Gonzales (Bounce Back) | attendance = }} The '''2014 Philippine Basketball Marathon''' is the longest basketball match played according to the [[Guinness World Records]]. The basketball game which was contested by Team Walang Iwanan and Team Bounce Back took place from 24–29 March 2014 at the Meralco Gym in Metro Manila. The match had a duration of 120 hours, one minute and 7.8 seconds. The marathon was a fund raising event to provide housing in an area in [[Negros Occidental]] which was devastated from [[Typhoon Haiyan|Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda)]]. The marathon broke the record set at the [[Missouri Athletic Club]] which took place in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], on March 21–25, 2012 with the game duration of 112 hours and 13 seconds. ==Background== The Philippine Basketball Marathon was a Guinness world record attempt to beat the record set at the [[Missouri Athletic Club]] which took place in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], from March 21–25, 2012 with the game duration of 112 hours and 13 seconds.{{cite news|title=Gawad Kalinga, ACCESS hold marathon basketball|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2014/03/16/1301544/gawad-kalinga-access-hold-marathon-basketball|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=16 March 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Navarro|first1=June|title=PH cage marathon shatters world mark|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/148961/ph-cage-marathon-shatters-world-mark|accessdate=26 December 2014|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=30 March 2014}} The Missouri match was between Team Joplin and Team St. Louis with the game ending 11,588–11,506 in favor of Team Joplin. Guinness laid provisions that 24 players in two teams were to participate in the Missouri attempt. Six players from each team played while six either rested, ate or receive medical attention.{{cite news|last1=Letner|first1=Josh|title=Marathon basketball game raises more than $100,000 for Joplin|url=http://www.joplinglobe.com/news/local_news/marathon-basketball-game-raises-more-than-for-joplin/article_28bb3e2d-7bab-5921-be6e-6386834ac846.html|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=The Joplin Globe|date=25 March 2012}} The Philippine attempt also doubled as a charity event since it was also held as part of the "Bounce Back Phl" project which aimed to raise funds to construct a Basketball Marathon (BM) Village in an area in Negros Occidental which was left devastated following the aftermath of [[Typhoon Haiyan|Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda)]]. The funds raised will be transferred to the "Operation Walang Iwanan" ({{literal translation|Operation No One Is Left Behind}}) project of [[Gawad Kalinga]] for this purpose. The BM Village will contain 24 houses, a basketball court and a community hall where the beneficiaries of the project may participate in livelihood programs of the charity organization. Construction of the village was scheduled in mid-2014. Gawad Kalinga also partnered with Asian Cable Enterprises, Inc. to organize the match. Similarly, the Missouri match was a fundraiser for the recovery process following the aftermath of the [[2011 Joplin tornado]]. More than $100,000 was raised which was distributed by the Joplin Area Chamber of Commerce. ==Preparation== ===Roster selection=== In 2013, 300,000 online applicants vied to be included in the two teams of the 2014 Philippine Basketball Marathon. From these, 100 were shortlisted. The 100 were evaluated by coaches on their basketball playing skills and overall fitness and 30 players were selected for another shortlist of 30 players. 24 players were then selected for the final 24.{{cite news|title=A league of non-pros readies for attempt at longest basketball game world record|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/353823/sports/basketball/a-league-of-non-pros-readies-for-attempt-at-longest-basketball-game-world-record|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=GMA News|date=23 March 2014|language=English, Filipino}} All in all the selection process included two try outs, extensive medical test and a panel interview held within two days.{{cite news|last1=Giongco|first1=Mark|title=But with a twist. No timeouts, no halftime break and fouls of each players will go back to zero every two hours.|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/147388/basketball-marathon-officials-confident-ph-can-break-record|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=The Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=11 March 2014}} Head coach Johnedel Cardel who leads the basketball team of the [[Rizal Technological University]] remarked that a mix of young and more mature teams for the final 24 was deliberate and said that the basketball match was less than physical endurance and more on mental toughness and perseverance. The selected players passed a series of medical tests and doctor consultations at [[The Medical City]] to ensure that they have the capability to play basketball for more than 112 hours. ===Training=== The players involved in the match underwent training and physical conditioning at the [[Rizal Technological University]]. The focus of the training was to enhance the players' stamina by developing their legs and lower back. To build the players' endurance, the coaches introduced cardio workouts, plyometics, and physical conditioning exercises and routines from [[association football|football]]. The players also had a high-protein diet. ===Match day=== Doctors and three ambulances were deployed in standby as a precautionary measure during the game. ==Format== The match was played under [[FIBA]] rules. There were no [[Time-out (sport)|time outs]] and halftime break. Fouls of all players reverts to 0 every 2 hours. Guinness has set guidelines that players should "play within the spirit of the rules of the sport" and are not leave the court in the entire duration of the match. ==Match details== The match tip off was scheduled at 07:00 [[Philippine Standard Time|PST]]{{cite news|title=24 cagers start basketball marathon today|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2014/03/24/1304447/24-cagers-start-basketball-marathon-today|accessdate=26 December 2014|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=24 March 2014}} but the game started at some hours later than initially planned at 09:00.{{cite news|last1=Beltran|first1=Nelson|title=Phl Basketball Marathon breaks Guinness mark|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2014/03/30/1306741/phl-basketball-marathon-breaks-guinness-mark|accessdate=26 December 2014|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=30 March 2014}} [[Pasig]] Mayor Bobby Eusebio and [[Samahang Basketball ng Pilipinas]] executive director [[Sonny Barrios]] were invited to kick off the event. {{basketballbox|date=24–29 March 2014|time=09:00 |place=Meralco Gym, [[Pasig]] | teamA = Team Walang Iwanan | scoreA = 16,732 | teamB = '''Team Bounce Back''' | scoreB = '''16,783''' |report= |points1= |rebounds1= |assist1= |points2= |rebounds2= |assist2= |referee= |attendance= }} {| style="width:92%;" |- |{{Basketball kit | pattern_b = | pattern_s = _blue stripes | body = FFFFFF | shorts = FFFFFF | title = {{nowrap|Walang Iwanan}} }} ||{{Basketball kit | body = 0026FF | pattern_b = | shorts = 0026FF | pattern_s = _white flash | title = {{nowrap|Bounce Back}} }} |} {| style="width:100%;" |- |valign=top width=50% align=center| {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:0px; font-size: 85%;" |- !colspan=4 style="background-color:#FFFFFF; color:#183192;" |Walang Iwanan roster |- ! Players !! Age !! Height !! Nickname{{refn|The nicknames of the players as displayed on the home page of the 2014 Philippine Basketball Marathon, which shows the final 24 players for Teams Walang Iwanan and Bounce Back (12 players each). The players name, age and height are not listed in this source.{{cite web|title=Home |url=http://basketballmarathonph.com/news.html |website=Basketball Marathon 2014 |accessdate=19 March 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214201228/http://basketballmarathonph.com/news.html |archivedate=February 14, 2015 |dead-url=yes }}
But an earlier source material by the organizers of the event{{cite news|author1=From the wires|title=Thirteen students, 14 others survive penultimate cut for Basketball Marathon record attempt|url=http://www.spin.ph/sports/basketball/news/basketball-marathon-guinness-record-attempt-final-30-players|publisher=Sports Interactive Network Philippines|date=10 March 2014}} showing the 30 player shortlist for the match. Chuck Williams previously goes by the nickname "CoCo La FaTain" as attested in the earlier source.|group="note"|name="nickname"}} |- |{{sortname|Sandy|Canel|nolink=y}}||20||{{height|ft=6|in=3|precision=2}}||Bohol |- |{{sortname|Paul Michael|dela Peña|nolink=y}}||24||{{height|ft=6|in=1|precision=2}}||Dels |- |{{sortname|Robie Dell|Macatbag|nolink=y}}||27||{{height|ft=5|in=11|precision=2}}||CDK |- |{{sortname|Hazel|Foja|nolink=y}}||28||{{height|ft=5|in=9|precision=2}}||Romblon |- |{{sortname|Adine Rome|Santos|nolink=y}}{{refn|The identity of the players identified as "Kopo", "Din" and "Kotkot" was not retrieved, although a report by the ''[[Philippine Star]]'' says that Adin Rome Santos, Renell Montecillo, and Jopet Quiro also participated in the basketball match who were not listed in the 30-player shortlist. Santos was identified to have played for Team Bounce Back. No source has been retrieved if the players used any of the three aliases.|group="note"|name="unknownplayers"}} ||colspan=3{{N/A}} |- |{{sortname|Owen|Mabaga|nolink=y}}||29||{{height|ft=5|in=9|precision=2}}||Engineer |- |{{sortname|Luis Jay|Volante|nolink=y}}||21||{{height|ft=5|in=5|precision=2}}||Baki |- |{{sortname|Harold|Lomtong|nolink=y}}||20||{{height|ft=5|in=7|precision=2}}||Haio |- |{{sortname|Evan|Lazana|nolink=y}}||43||{{height|ft=5|in=11|precision=2}}||Bidoy |- |{{sortname|Abraham|Compuesto III|nolink=y}}||19||{{height|ft=6|in=0|precision=2}}||AC |- |{{sortname|Jeffrey|Moore|nolink=y}}{{refn|There were three American nationals who participated in the game, Moore, Tater, and Williams. All three were participants of the 2012 Missouri Athletic Club game which were the previous holders of the world record which this game successfully broke.|group="note"|name="american"}}||47||{{height|ft=5|in=9|precision=2}}||J Mo |- |{{sortname|Tony|Tater|nolink=y}}||45||{{height|ft=6|in=1|precision=2}}||Tatertot |-class="sortbottom" !colspan=4|Head Coach: Johnedel Cardel{{cite news|last1=Beltran|first1=Nelson|title=Gutsy Pinoy cagers take shot at world longest game|url=https://news.abs-cbn.com/sports/03/25/14/gutsy-pinoy-cagers-take-shot-world-longest-game|accessdate=5 February 2018|work=ABS-CBN|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=25 March 2014}} |} | style="vertical-align:top; width:50%;"| {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:0px; font-size: 85%;" |- !colspan=4 style="background-color:#183192; color:#FFFFFF;" |Bounce Back roster |- ! Players !! Age !! Height !! Nickname |- |{{sortname|Larry|Macapanpan|nolink=y}}||43||{{height|ft=5|in=6|precision=2}}||Doc |- |{{sortname|Helino|Francisco Jr.|nolink=y}}||24||{{height|ft=6|in=1|precision=2}}||D Mole |- |{{sortname|Kerr|Bangeles|nolink=y}}||22||{{height|ft=5|in=10|precision=2}}||Kerr |- |{{sortname|Renell|Montecillo|nolink=y}}||colspan=3{{N/A}} |- |{{sortname|John Ray|Mapala|nolink=y}}||22||{{height|ft=5|in=9|precision=2}}||JhayQuick |- |{{sortname|Jopet|Quiro|nolink=y}}||colspan=3{{N/A}} |- |{{sortname|Justo|Quita Jr.|nolink=y}}||23||{{height|ft=5|in=9|precision=2}}||Batang |- |{{sortname|Rober Clark|Bear|nolink=y}}||20||{{height|ft=6|in=1|precision=2}}||Papa Bear |- |{{sortname|Maricar|Convencido|nolink=y}}{{refn|Not all participants were male, Convencido is the sole female participant in the game. She is a Physical Education instructor and basketball coach|group="note"|name="onlywoman"}}||29||{{height|ft=5|in=3|precision=2}}||Riki |- |{{sortname|Santos|Tominio|nolink=y}}||20||{{height|ft=5|in=8|precision=2}}||Esjey |- |{{sortname|Chuck|Williams|nolink=y}}||48||{{height|ft=6|in=0|precision=2}}||C-Dub |- |{{sortname|Carlo Ferdinand|Vasquez|nolink=y}}||28||{{height|ft=5|in=7|precision=2}}||Grummann |- |-class="sortbottom" !colspan=4|Head Coach: Louie Gonzales |} |} ===Notes=== {{Reflist|group=note}} ==Aftermath== The game that began around 09:00 [[Philippine Standard Time|PST]] in March 24 ended around the same time in March 29. By around 1:00 am in March 29, the world record set at the Missouri Athletics Club was broken. The whole game's duration was 120 hours, one minute and 7.8 seconds. ===Verification by Guinness=== Following the end of the game, Guinness didn't immediately recognize the world record accomplished by the basketball match and underwent a review by a Guinness adjudicator if there were violations to the provisions laid by the world record organization.{{cite news|last1=Giongco|first1=Mark|title=PH sets record but won’t be official until Guinness approves|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/148866/ph-sets-record-but-wont-be-official-until-guinness-approves|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=29 March 2014}} Access Discovery Channel was concerned that Guinness won't recognize the feat due to technicality reasons. Jacque Ruby, chief operating officer of organization is cited two guidelines which states that participants “have to play within the spirit of the rules of the sport” and the other is the prohibition of players from leaving the court. Ruby noted that during the "graveyard shift" players are "not running anymore, stays at the other end and just waits for the ball" which he says that "it's not an actual game anymore. He also noted that players also occasionally went to the toilet which is located outside the court. The guidelines set for Guinness were reportedly strict compared to when it verified the Missouri Athletic Club match. Were a smaller board was used and there was no 24-second shot clock. The Missouri Athletic Club attempt was not recorded in videotape in whole and players were allowed to play barefoot. In March 30, 2014, radio station [[DZBB-AM]] reported that Guinness has officially recognized the new world record set by the Philippine Basketball Marathon.{{cite news|title=Now it's official: PHL new world record holder in marathon basketball|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/354740/sports/basketball/now-it-s-official-phl-new-world-record-holder-in-marathon-basketball|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=GMA News|date=30 March 2016}} ===Recognition=== House Resolution 01487 was adopted in the [[Philippine House of Representatives]] in September 10, 2014 to congratulate and commend the two teams, along with the Samahang Basketball ng Pilipinas organizing committee for the world record feat. The resolution was authored by Eric Olivares and Anthony Del Rosario of the Committee on Youth and Sports Development.{{cite web|last1=Olivares|first1=Eric|last2=Del Rosario|first2=Anthony|title=House Resolution 01487|url=http://www.congress.gov.ph/download/basic_16/HR01487.pdf|publisher=House of Representatives (Philippines)|accessdate=19 March 2016}} The Philippine Basketball Marathon received a citation at the [[2015 PSA Annual Awards]].{{cite news|title=PSA honors 2014’s best athletes|url=http://manilastandardtoday.com/sports/170717/psa-honors-2014-s-best-athletes.html|accessdate=19 March 2016|work=The Standard Sports|date=16 February 2015}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150215024841/http://basketballmarathonph.com/index.html Marathon 2014 Official Website] (Archived) ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Basketball Marathon}} [[Category:2013–14 in Philippine basketball]] [[Category:Basketball games in the Philippines]] [[Category:Charity events]] [[Category:Sports world records]]

==2015–16 [[Ladies Professional Racquetball Tour]]==

[[Maria Jose Vargas]] 11-13, 11-2, 11-6, 11-3. *** {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Paola Longoria]] / {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Samantha Salas]] def. {{flagicon|USA}} [[Michelle Key]] / {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Frédérique revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
The following are the events in professional [[sumo]] during 2017.
==Tournaments== *Hatsu [[honbasho|basho]], [[Ryōgoku Kokugikan]], [[Tokyo]], 8 January – 22 January<ref name="tournaments">{{cite web|url=http://sumo.or.jp/EnTicket/year_schedule|title=Grand Tournament Schedule |publisher=[[Japan Sumo Association]]}}</ref> *Haru basho, [[Osaka Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Osaka]], 12 March – 26 March<ref name="tournaments"/> *Natsu basho, Ryōgoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 14 May – 28 May<ref name="tournaments"/> *Nagoya basho, [[Aichi Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Nagoya]], 9 July – 23 July<ref name="tournaments"/> *Aki basho, Ryōgoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 10 September – 24 September<ref name="tournaments"/> *Kyushu basho, [[Fukuoka Kokusai Center]], [[Kyushu]], 12 November – 26 November<ref name="tournaments"/>
==News==
===January=== [[File:Kisenosato Yutaka1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kisenosato]]'s first public ''yokozuna'' duties at the [[Meiji Shrine]] on January 27]] *6: The three Mongolian ''[[yokozuna]]'' [[Hakuhō]], [[Kakuryū Rikisaburō|Kakuryū]] and [[Harumafuji]] attend a New Year ceremony at the [[Meiji Shrine]], and perform the ''[[dohyo-iri]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/hakuho-leads-traditional-new-year-stomping-ceremony-in-tokyo/3419180.html|title=Hakuho leads traditional new year stomping ceremony in Tokyo|date=6 January 2017|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref> *21: ''[[Ōzeki]]'' [[Kisenosato]] wins his first ''[[yūshō]]'' or top division championship, after seeing Hakuhō fall to ''[[maegashira]]'' [[Takanoiwa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kyodonews.net/news/2017/01/21/97227|title=Sumo: Kisenosato finally meets championship expectations|date=21 January 2017|publisher=Kyodo News|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> Kisenosato, at 13–1, is two wins ahead of Hakuhō who drops to 11–3, with only one day to go. Kisenosato had been a runner-up on twelve previous occasions. *22: On the final day of the Hatsu basho, Kisenosato wraps up his first championship by defeating Hakuhō in the last bout of the day to finish with a 14–1 record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170123/p2a/00m/0na/011000c|title=After years of persistence, Kisenosato ready to rise to sumo's pinnacle|date=23 January 2017|publisher=The Mainichi|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> Hakuho, on 11–4, has gone four tournaments without winning a championship for the first time in his ten-year ''yokozuna'' career. The runner-up is rank-and-file ''maegashira'' [[Sokokurai]] on 12–3, who wins his first [[sansho (sumo)|special prize]] (for Technique) at the age of 33. He shares the award with [[Mitakeumi]], whose 11–4 record gives him a strong case for promotion back to the ''[[sanyaku]]'' ranks. The Outstanding Performance Award goes to Takanoiwa (11–4) for his win over Hakuhō. [[Takayasu Akira|Takayasu]] wins his fourth Fighting Spirit prize. ''Ōzeki'' [[Terunofuji]] and [[Kotoshōgiku]] both finish with poor 5–10 records. It is Kotoshōgiku's second [[make-koshi|losing score]] in a row and he will be demoted to ''[[sekiwake]]'' for the following tournament. The ''[[jūryō]]'' division championship is won by [[Daieishō Hayato|Daieishō]]. *22: The process to promote Kisenosato to ''yokozuna'' begins as the [[judge (sumo)|judge]]s division of the [[Japan Sumo Association]] asks chairman [[Hokutoumi Nobuyoshi|Hakkaku Oyakata]] to hold an extraordinary meeting of its directors, and he agrees.<ref name="drought">{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201701230040.html|title=SUMO/ Kisenosato to end long drought of Japan-born yokozuna|date=23 January 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> *23: Hakkaku asks the [[Yokozuna Deliberation Council]] about whether Kisenosato is deserving of promotion to ''yokozuna''. The council decide that he is suitable.<ref name="drought"/> Speaking at a press conference, Kisenosato recalls the words of his late stablemaster [[Takanosato]] who was also a ''yokozuna''. "He said that 'being a yokozuna is lonely'. I don’t know its meaning yet. But I will make efforts so that I will be able to understand the meaning."<ref name="drought"/> *25: Kisenosato's ''yokozuna'' promotion is confirmed by the Sumo Association's board of directors in a unanimous decision. [[Tochinowaka Kiyotaka|Kasugano]] and [[Akinoshima|Takadagawa]] convey the message to Kisenosato and his stablemaster [[Takanotsuru Shinichi|Tagonoura]] at a hotel in Tokyo's [[Chiyoda ward]]. Kisenosato says "I am honoured to accept the decision. I will do my best not to tarnish the title of yokozuna."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201701250074.html|title=SUMO/ Kisenosato ends barren spell for Japan-born yokozuna|date=25 January 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> *27: Kisenosato performs the ''yokozuna'' ring-entering ceremony ''([[dohyo-iri]])'' for the first time in public in front of a crowd of 18000 at the [[Meiji Shrine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/01/27/sumo/yokozuna-kisenosato-carries-first-ring-entry-ceremony/#.WIugCk0zUy8|title=Yokozuna Kisenosato carries out first ring-entry ceremony|date=27 January 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> *31: Magaki Oyakata, former ''[[komusubi]]'' [[Tokitenkū Yoshiaki|Tokitenkū]], dies of [[malignant lymphoma]] at the age of 37. He had retired only last August. His fellow Mongolian Hakuhō pays tribute by saying "I’m in my 30s too, it came too early. He was full of fight when I first faced him, I struggled to see eye to eye. I always had to be careful about his good footwork."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/01/31/sumo/ex-komusubi-tokitenku-dies-37/#.WJCUd2czWUk|title=Ex-komusubi Tokitenku dies at 37|date=31 January 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref>
===February=== *3: Kisenosato and Hakuho throw soy beans at the [[Narita-san]] temple in [[Narita, Chiba]] Prefecture as part of the annual festival to celebrate [[Setsubun]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201702030049.html|title=Crowd-pleasing Kisenosato chucks soybeans for good luck|date=3 February 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> *5: The 41st [[Fuji TV]] Grand Sumo Tournament takes place at the [[Ryogoku Kokugikan]]. Yokozuna Kisenosato performs his ''dohyo-iri'' in the Kokugikan for the first time. The event is a knock-out format. In the ''makuuchi'' competition, the top eight men on the Hatsu tournament ''banzuke'' are seeded (except for Harumafuji and [[Goeido]] who are injured and do not take part) – Kakuryu (1), Hakuho (2), Kisenosato (3), Terunofuji (4), Kotoshogiku (5), Tamawashi (6), [[Shōdai Naoya|Shodai]] (7) and Takayasu (8). Kisenosato wins the tournament, defeating Takanoiwa in the final. The ''juryo'' tournament is won by [[Kyokutaisei]] who defeats [[Seirō Takeshi|Seiro]]. *11:The 50th [[NHK]] Charity Sumo Tournament takes place, also at the Kokugikan. This time Harumafuji attends along with the other three ''yokozuna''. Several wrestlers take part in a [[enka|singing]] competition with partners or groups: Hakuho with [[Rimi Natsukawa]], Harumafuji with [[Natsuko Godai]], Kakuryu with [[Midori Oka]], Terunofuji with [[Team Syachihoko]], Takayasu with [[Ai Nishida]] and [[Ikioi Shōta|Ikioi]] with [[Yoshimi Tendo]]. *27: The ''banzuke'' for the March tournament is released. Kisenosato is listed on the west side at ''yokozuna'' rank, the first Japanese born wrestler since Takanohana in 2003 to be yokozuna on the ''banzuke''. There are three ''sekiwake'' following Kotoshogiku's demotion from ''ozeki''. It is the first time since 1949 that there has been a promotion of a yokozuna and a demotion of an ozeki in the same tournament.<ref name="topics">{{cite web|url=http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnHonbashoTopics/banzuke_topics |title=2017 March Grand Sumo Tournament Banzuke Topics |date=February 2017 |publisher=Japan Sumo Association |accessdate=27 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227172115/http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnHonbashoTopics/banzuke_topics |archivedate=27 February 2017 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The only newcomer to the top division is [[Ura Kazuki|Ura]]. He is the first former student of [[Kwansei Gakuin University]] to reach the top division.<ref name="topics"/> Making his ''juryo'' debut is [[Takasago stable]]'s [[Asanoyama Hideki|Asanoyama]], the first ''[[sekitori]]'' from [[Toyama Prefecture]] since [[Kotogaume]] in 1997.<ref name="topics"/> His promotion means Takasago stable has a ''sekitori'' again after they had none in the previous tournament for the first time in their history.
===March=== *12: The Osaka tournament begins with four ''yokozuna'' competing in a ''[[honbasho]]'' for the first time in 17 years.<ref name="hakuho">{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170316/p2g/00m/0sp/058000c|title=Sumo: Kisenosato keeps winning run going at Spring sumo|date=16 March 2017|publisher=The Mainichi|accessdate=29 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317143105/http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170316/p2g/00m/0sp/058000c|archive-date=2017-03-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *17: Hakuho withdraws from the tournament because of toe and thigh injuries.<ref name="hakuho"/> *24: Having compiled a perfect 12–0 record thus far, Kisenosato loses for the first time as a ''yokozuna'' on Day 13, defeated by Harumafuji. He is injured during the match and leaves the arena with his arm in a sling, but does not withdraw from the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170325/p2g/00m/0sp/041000c|title=Sumo: Yokozuna Kisenosato to fight in Spring tourney despite injury|date=25 March 2017|publisher=The Mainichi|accessdate=29 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170326050535/http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170325/p2g/00m/0sp/041000c|archive-date=2017-03-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *26: In a remarkable final day's action, Kisenosato comes from behind to win the tournament by defeating Terunofuji twice – once in their regulation match and again in a playoff.<ref name="kisenosato">{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170326/p2g/00m/0sp/039000c|title=Sumo: Yokozuna Kisenosato denies Terunofuji to win Spring title|date=26 March 2017|publisher=The Mainichi|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> He finishes on 13–2, his only two defeats in the tournament being to his fellow ''yokozuna'' Harumafuji and Kakuryu (who both finish with mediocre 10–5 records). He is the first ''yokozuna'' to win his debut tournament since [[Takanohana]] in January 1995.<ref name="kisenosato"/> Terunofuji, seemingly recovered from the knee problems that dogged him throughout 2016, not only saves his ''ozeki'' rank but has his first runner-up performance since September 2015.<ref name="kisenosato"/> Kisenosato's stablemate Takayasu was the only other wrestler to defeat Terunofuji and finishes with a fine 12–3 record and his third Outstanding Performance Award.<ref name="kisenosato"/> [[Takakeisho]] receives the Fighting Spirit Prize after winning eleven in only his second top division tournament.<ref name="kisenosato"/> ''Sekiwake'' Kotoshogiku fails in his bid to return immediately to the ''ozeki'' rank, finishing on 9–6, one win short of his minimum target of ten. His sixth defeat on Day 14 saw the crowd boo his opponent, Terunofuji, after Kotoshogiku fell victim to the ''[[henka]]'' manoeuvre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/03/25/sumo/basho-reports/leader-terunofuji-bolsters-title-hopes/#.WNvCCk0zXoo|title=Leader Terunofuji bolsters title hopes|date=25 March 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> The ''juryo'' division championship is won by veteran [[Toyohibiki]] for the third time after a three-way playoff. Down in the ''[[jonokuchi]]'' division the 46 year-old Hokutoryu announces his retirement after 31 years and 186 tournaments in sumo, leaving [[Hanakaze Daisaku|Hanakaze]] (who made his debut alongside Hokutoryu in March 1986) as the last active wrestler from the [[Shōwa era]].
===April=== [[File:大相撲川崎場所 2017 (33234083763).jpg|thumb|right|Wrestlers during the April 13 stop in [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa]]]] *1: Naruto Oyakata, the former ''ozeki'' [[Kotooshu]], branches out from [[Sadogatake stable]] and opens his own [[Naruto stable (2017)|Naruto stable]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/04/01/sumo/ex-ozeki-kotooshu-opens-stable/#.WOUDQGczXoo|title=Ex-ozeki Kotooshu opens own stable|date=1 April 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=5 April 2017}}</ref> *The spring regional tour visits the following locations: **2: [[Ise Shrine]] (Honozumo ceremonial tournament held in the shine’s precincts), [[Mie Prefecture]] **3: [[Komaki, Aichi]] Prefecture **4: [[Kato, Hyogo]] Prefecture **5: [[Takarazuka, Hyogo]] Prefecture **6: [[Himeji, Hyogo]] Prefecture **8: [[Fujisawa, Kanagawa]] Prefecture **9: [[Shizuoka, Shizuoka]] Prefecture **11: [[Mishima, Shizuoka]] Prefecture **12: [[Yokosuka, Kanagawa]] Prefecture **13: [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa]] Prefecture **14: [[Matsumoto, Nagano]] Prefecture **15: [[Takasaki, Gunma]] Prefecture **16: [[Hitachiomiya, Ibaraki]] Prefecture **17:[[Yasukuni Shrine]] (Honozumo ceremonial tournament held in the shrine’s precincts), [[Tokyo]] **20: [[Kashiwa, Chiba]] Prefecture **21: [[Mito, Ibaraki]] Prefecture **22: [[Hachioji, Tokyo]] Prefecture **23: [[Machida, Tokyo]] Prefecture **24: [[Fukaya, Saitama]] Prefecture **29: Chokaigi basho, [[Chiba Prefecture]] *27: Former ''yokozuna'' [[Sadanoyama]], who served as the head of the Japan Sumo Association from 1992 to 1998, dies of pneumonia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former yokozuna Sadanoyama dies at 79|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/05/01/sumo/former-yokozuna-sadanoyama-dies-79/#.WQnK1ly7XBV|website=The Japan Times|accessdate=3 May 2017}}</ref> This leaves [[Tochinoumi]] as the oldest living former ''yokozuna''.
===May=== *1: The ''banzuke'' for the May tournament is released. Two wrestlers make their top division debut: [[Ōnoshō Fumiya|Ōnoshō]] from [[Onomatsu stable]], and [[Yutakayama Ryōta|Yutakayama]] from [[Tokitsukaze stable]]. Onosho is the fifth wrestler to reach ''makuuchi'' from Onomatsu stable since it was founded in 1994.<ref name="may topics">{{cite web|title=2017 May Grand Sumo Tournament Banzuke Topics|url=http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnHonbashoTopics/banzuke_topics|website=Japan Sumo Association|accessdate=3 May 2017}}</ref> Yutakayama debuts in ''makuuchi'' a year after his stablemate [[Shodai]]. Both are former students of the Tokyo University of Agriculture. Yutakayama also makes history as the first ever [[Glossary_of_sumo_terms#sandanme_tsukedashi|''sandanme'' tsukedashi]] to make his ''makuuchi'' debut.<ref name="may topics"/> [[Chiyonokuni]] and [[Chiyoshoma]] of the [[Kokonoe stable]] reach their highest career ranks, at ''maegashira 1'' and ''maegashira 2'', respectively. [[Yoshikaze]] returns to ''[[sanyaku]]'' after seven tournaments. Hakuhō is ranked at ''yokozuna'' for the 59th time on the ''banzuke'', level with [[Chiyonofuji]] and behind only [[Kitanoumi]] with 63.<ref name="may topics"/> *24: Having failed to recover sufficiently from his upper body injuries sustained in the last tournament, Kisenosato withdraws after four losses in the first ten days. He had previously missed only one bout in his career, the last day of the January 2014 tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201705240025.html|title=SUMO/ Injury ends Kisenosato's bid for 3rd straight Emperor's Cup|date=24 May 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=30 May 2017}}</ref> *28: Hakuhō wraps up his 38th ''yūshō'' (and first in a year)<ref name="asahi">{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201705270045.html|title=SUMO/ Hakuho wins for 1st time in a year and grabs his 38th career title|date=27 May 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=30 May 2017}}</ref> by defeating Harumafuji to claim his 13th ''zensho-yūshō'' or perfect score of 15 wins and no losses. Second place is shared by ''ōzeki'' Terunofuji and ''maegashira'' [[Tochinoshin]] on 12–3. Ōnoshō scores 10–5 in his top division debut and receives the Fighting Spirit Award. The Outstanding Performance Prize goes to ''komusubi'' Mitakeumi for defeating two ''yokozuna''. The Technique Prize is shared between Yoshikaze and Takayasu, who with 11 wins in this tournament and a 34–11 record over the last three tournaments is virtually certain to be promoted to ''ōzeki''.<ref name="asahi"/> The ''jūryō'' division championship is won by [[Nishikigi]] with a score of 10–5 who defeats [[Aminishiki]], denying the veteran the chance to win his first championship in any division at the age of 38. Another veteran, former ''maegashira'' [[Ōiwato Yoshiyuki|Ōiwato]], does claim his first ''[[makushita]]'' championship at the age of 36. Announcing their retirements are former ''sekiwake'' [[Asasekiryū]] and former ''maegashira'' [[Sadanofuji]], who are staying in sumo as Nishikijima Oyakata and Nakamura Oyakata respectively. *31: Takayasu is formally promoted to ''ōzeki''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2017/05/3f54f821de5e-update1-sumo-takayasu-officially-promoted-to-ozeki.html|title=Sumo: Takayasu officially promoted to ozeki|date=31 May 2017|publisher=Kyodo News|}}</ref>
===June=== *1: The Sumo Association announce that the Nagoya tournament in the year 2020 will start a week earlier than normal to avoid clashing with that year's [[2020 Summer Olympics|Tokyo Summer Olympics]] which is scheduled to begin on July 24, 2020. The sumo will now conclude on July 19.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/06/01/sumo/nagoya-basho-begin-earlier-2020-avoid-scheduling-clash-tokyo-olympics/#.WUKsfU2WyM8|title=Nagoya Basho to begin earlier in 2020 to avoid scheduling clash with Tokyo Olympics|date=1 June 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=15 June 2017}}</ref> *11: Ex-''sekiwake'' [[Kyokutenhō]] takes over as the head coach of [[Tomozuna stable]] from former ''sekiwake'' [[Kaiki Nobuhide|Kaiki]], as the latter has reached 65 years of age. The former Tomozuna is however re-hired by the Sumo Association as a consultant on reduced pay for five years, and is now known as Ōshima Oyakata. *25: The ''banzuke'' for the July tournament in Nagoya is released. There are no wrestlers making their top division debuts for the first time since May 2015,<ref name="spotlight">{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/06/26/sumo/takayasu-set-enter-spotlight-ozeki-nagoya-basho/#.WVE1kE2Wzop|title=Takayasu set for spotlight as ozeki at Nagoya meet|website=The Japan Times|date=26 June 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=26 June 2017}}</ref> but [[Gagamaru]], [[Chiyomaru]], [[Sadanoumi Takashi|Sadanoumi]] and Nishikigi return, replacing [[Kaisei Ichirō|Kaisei]], [[Myogiryu]], Toyohibiki and Yutakayama who are all demoted to ''juryo''. With Takayasu's promotion there are four ''yokozuna'' and three ''ozeki'' on the ''banzuke'' for the first time since March 2000.<ref name="spotlight"/> Mitakeumi makes his debut at ''[[sekiwake]].'' The sole new ''[[sekitori]]'' is {{Interlanguage link multi|Iwasaki Masaya|ja|3=岩崎正也|lt=Tobizaru}} (previously known by his family name of Iwasaki), while [[Abi Masatora|Abi]] returns to the ''juryo'' division.
===July=== *23: The Nagoya tournament concludes with Hakuhō defeating Harumafuji to win his 39th yusho, his 14–1 record ensuring that he finishes one win ahead of rank-and filer [[Aoiyama]] on 13–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201707230023.html|title=SUMO/ Hakuho extends his career tournament title record to 39|date=23 July 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref> During the basho Hakuhō established a new record of total career wins, surpassing both [[Chiyonofuji]]'s 1045 and [[Kaiō Hiroyuki|Kaiō]]'s 1047. The record-breaking 1048th win came on Day 13 against new ozeki Takayasu.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/83f35b4a4e374878b8221e7232c7393f|title=Mongolian grand champ Hakuho sets record 1,048 wins in sumo|date=21 July 2017|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref> Aoiyama is runner-up for the first time in his career and wins the Fighting Spirit Award. The Outstanding Performance Prize goes to Mitakeumi, who was the only man to beat Hakuhō. The tournament sees a number of high profile withdrawals due to injury, including yokozuna Kisenosato and Kakuryū, ozeki Terunofuji and maegashira [[Endō Shōta|Endō]]. The ''juryo'' division championship is won by [[Daiamami Genki|Daiamami]]. *27: [[Asahifuji Seiya|Isegahama Oyakata]] says that Harumafuji may need surgery on a left elbow injury and is likely to miss the Aki basho in September if that occurs. He also indicates that Terunofuji will miss the whole of the summer regional tour or ''jungyo'' as he continues to recover from knee surgery in May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/07/27/sumo/harumafuji-may-need-undergo-elbow-surgery/#.WXpBE02Wzoo|title=Harumafuji may need to undergo elbow surgery|date=27 July 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref> *The summer regional tour visits the following locations: **30: [[Gifu, Gifu]] Prefecture **31: [[Kusatsu, Shiga]] Prefecture
===August=== *The summer regional tour will visit the following locations:<ref name="jungyo">{{cite web|url=http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnJungyo/schedule/|title=2017 Tour Schedule|publisher=Japan Sumo Association|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170725163057/http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnJungyo/schedule/|archivedate=25 July 2017}}</ref> **1: [[Toyota, Aichi]] Prefecture **2: [[Toyama, Toyama]] Prefecture **3: [[Shibata, Niigata]] Prefecture **5: [[Sado, Niigata]] Prefecture **6: [[Nagaoka, Niigata]] Prefecture **7: [[Honjo, Saitama]] Prefecture **8: [[Aoyama Gakuin]], Tokyo Prefecture **10: [[Hitachi, Ibaraki]] Prefecture **11: [[Kaminoyama, Yamagata]] Prefecture **12–13: [[Sendai, Miyagi]] Prefecture **15: [[Aomori, Aomori]] Prefecture **16: [[Itayanagi, Aomori]] Prefecture **18: [[Eniwa, Hokkaido]] Prefecture **19: [[Sapporo, Hokkaido]] Prefecture **20: [[Asahikawa, Hokkaido]] Prefecture **23–24: [[Odaiba|Odaiba, Tokyo]] Prefecture **25: [[Odawara, Kanagawa]] Prefecture **26: [[Tokorozawa, Saitama]] Prefecture **27: [[JP Tower|KITTE, Tokyo]] Prefecture
*10: Former ''juryo'' wrestler [[Dewaotori]] announces his retirement after 13 years in sumo. *22: The Russian ''[[sandanme]]'' wrestler [[Ōrora Satoshi|Ōrora]] is announced as the heaviest ever ''rikishi'' in sumo, his weight recorded as {{convert|288|kg|lb|abbr=on}} in the latest weigh-in conducted by the Sumo Association, surpassing [[Konishiki]]'s peak weight of {{convert|285|kg|lb|abbr=on}} in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hochi.co.jp/sports/sumo/20170822-OHT1T50111.html|title=ロシア出身・大露羅、体重２８８キロ！小錦の２８５キロ抜き歴代１位に「永遠に名前が残りますから」|date=22 August 2017|publisher=Hochi|accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref> *28: The banzuke for the Aki basho is released. Yoshikaze becomes the fifth oldest post-WWII ''sekiwake'' at 35 years and 5 months.<ref name="jsa">{{cite web|url=http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnHonbashoTopics/banzuke_topics/|title=2017 September Grand Sumo Tournament Banzuke Topics|date=30 August 2017|publisher=Japan Sumo Association|accessdate=31 August 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831193417/http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnHonbashoTopics/banzuke_topics/|archivedate=31 August 2017}}</ref> [[Asanoyama]] makes his ''makuuchi'' debut. He is the first wrestler from [[Takasago stable]] to be promoted to the top division since [[Asasekiryū]] in March 2003.<ref name="jsa"/> He is also the first wrestler from [[Toyama Prefecture]] to be ranked in makuuchi since [[Kotogaume]] in January 1995.<ref name="jsa"/> He is the second ''[[sandanme tsukedashi]]'' to reach the top division following [[Yutakayama Ryota|Yutakayama]], who returns to ''makuuchi'' for this tournament. There are two new ''sekitori'': [[Yago Takanori|Yago]] from [[Oguruma stable]] (a former amateur champion at [[Chuo University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/adv/chuo/dy/hakumon/2017earlyspring01.html|title=Looking up to Kisenosato as a role model|publisher=Japan News|accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref>) and [[Daiseidō Yoshitomo|Daiseidō]] from [[Kise stable (2003)|Kise stable]].
===September=== [[File:Rikishin 2017.jpg|thumb|left|Former ''juryo'' [[Rikishin]] retired through injury at age 21 in September]]{{-}} *7: It is announced that both Kisenosato and Kakuryū will skip the Aki ''basho'' as neither have fully recovered from their respective injuries. It is the first time since 1999 that two ''yokozuna'' have been absent from Day 1 of a tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/09/07/sumo/basho-reports/yokozuna-kisenosato-kakuryu-pull-autumn-basho/#.WbFWDk2Wzoo|title=Yokozuna Kisenosato, Kakuryu pull out of Autumn Basho|date=7 September 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> *8: Hakuhō also announces that he is withdrawing due to a knee injury, making this the first tournament since the start of the [[Shōwa era]] that three ''yokozuna'' are out.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201709080029.html|title=Hakuho pulls out of Tokyo basho; first time 3 yokozuna absent|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|date=8 September 2017|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> *15: Terunofuji withdraws due to his knee injury, joining fellow ''ozeki'' Takayasu who pulled out on Day 3. It is the first time since the Summer tournament of 1918 that three ''yokozuna'' and two ''ozeki'' have been missing through injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2017/09/15de69a1d17e-update1sumo-ozeki-terunofuji-latest-to-withdraw-from-autumn-tourney.html|title=Sumo: Ozeki Terunofuji latest to withdraw from Autumn tourney|date=15 September 2017|publisher=Kyodo News|accessdate=16 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170916160858/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2017/09/15de69a1d17e-update1sumo-ozeki-terunofuji-latest-to-withdraw-from-autumn-tourney.html|archivedate=16 September 2017}}</ref> *24:The Aki ''basho'' ends with Harumafuji defeating Goeido in a playoff after both finish with 11–4 records.<ref name="rally">{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201709240028.html|title=SUMO/ Harumafuji completes final-day rally, wins 9th title|date=24 September 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=25 September 2017}}</ref> Goeido had been two wins ahead of the rest of the field on Day 11 but lost three of his last four bouts, with Harumafuji defeating him twice on the final day to win his ninth championship.<ref name="rally"/> He is only the third wrestler to win a top division championship with a mere 11–4 record following [[Tochiazuma Tomoyori|Tochiazuma]] in 1972 and [[Musashimaru]] in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2017/09/a5b9d5eb265e-sumo-harumafuji-savors-sweet-taste-of-victory-sake-after-big-win.html|title=Sumo: Harumafuji savors sweet taste of victory sake after big win|date=25 September 2017|publisher=Kyodo News|accessdate=25 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170925201712/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2017/09/a5b9d5eb265e-sumo-harumafuji-savors-sweet-taste-of-victory-sake-after-big-win.html|archivedate=25 September 2017}}</ref> ''Makuuchi'' debutant [[Asanoyama]] wins the Fighting Spirit Award after a fine 10–5 record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-japan-news.com/news/article/0003962555|title=Harumafuji wins title in playoff|date=24 September 2017|publisher=Japan News|accessdate=25 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170925202039/http://www.the-japan-news.com/news/article/0003962555|archivedate=25 September 2017}}</ref> He shares the prize with [[Onosho]] who becomes the first man to secure double-digit winning records in his first three top division tournaments in the modern era.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/09/27/sumo/autumn-basho-flourishes-absence-stars/#.Wcu5JE2Wzoo|title=Autumn Basho flourishes in absence of stars|last=Gunning|first=John|date=27 September 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> The Technique Award goes to Yoshikaze for the fourth time. The Outstanding Performance Award is won by [[Takakeisho]] for defeating both Harumafuji and Goeido. The ''juryo'' championship is won by [[Abi Masatora|Abi]] with a 10–5 record after a four-way playoff that also involved [[Kotoyuki]] (who Abi beat earlier in the day as well), [[Aminishiki]] and [[Homarefuji]]. The ''makushita'' division championship is won by former maegashira [[Kagamio]] with a prefect 7–0 record. Two former ''juryo'' wrestlers, {{Interlanguage link multi|Wakanoshima|ja|3=若乃島史也}} and {{Interlanguage link multi|Rikishin|ja|3=力真樹}} announce their retirements. Wakanoshima is a 32 year old veteran with 17 years in sumo but Rikishin is just 21 years old and has failed to recover from recent knee surgery.
===October=== *2: Kisenosato wins the All Japan Rikishi Tournament, a knock-out exhibition at the Kokugikan, for the second year in a row.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXLSSXK10542_S7A001C1000000/|title=稀勢の里が２連覇 大相撲の全日本力士選士権|date=2 October 2017|publisher=Nikkei|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> He defeats [[Takekaze]] in the final. The ''jūryō'' tournament is held by [[Seirō Takeshi|Seiro]]. *4: The second Ozumo Beyond 2020 Basho, an exhibition aimed at foreign fans ahead of the [[2020 Summer Olympics]], is held at the Kokugikan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/09/25/sumo/jsa-offering-foreign-fans-rare-glimpse-special-sumo-rituals/#.Wc0b_U2Wzoo|title=JSA offering foreign fans rare glimpse of special sumo rituals|last=Gunning|first=John|date=27 September 2017|publisher=The Japan Times|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/10/04/sumo/sumo-pulls-stops-promotional-event/#.WdUwcE2Wzop|title=Sumo pulls out all the stops at promotional event|last=Yoshikawa|first=Mai|date=4 October 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> At its conclusion Hakuhō is presented with an award (an artwork of [[Japanese calligraphy]]) from the [[Yokozuna Deliberation Council]] to mark his achievement of breaking the all-time career wins record with his 1048th victory in July.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20171004/p2g/00m/0sp/072000c|title=Sumo: Hakuho receives special award for his all-time wins record|date=4 October 2017|publisher=The Mainichi|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref>
*The autumn regional tour will visit the following locations:<ref name="jungyo"/> **5: [[Yachiyo, Chiba]] **6: [[Yokohama, Kanagawa]] **7: [[Saitama, Saitama]] **8: [[Fuji, Shizuoka]] **9: [[Chikusei, Ibaraki]] **11: [[Hamamatsu, Shizuoka]] **12: [[Ichinomiya, Aichi]] **13: [[Nagano, Nagano]] **14: [[Kanazawa, Ishikawa]] **15: [[Kyoto, Kyoto]] **17: [[Takayama, Gifu]] **18: [[Tsu, Mie]] **19: [[Kashiba, Nara]] **20: [[Hirakata, Osaka]] **21: [[Kishiwada, Osaka]] **22: [[Osaka, Osaka]] **24: [[Okayama, Okayama ]] **25: [[Yabu, Hyogo]] **26: [[Tottori, Tottori]] **27: [[Matsue, Shimane]] **28: [[Hiroshima, Hiroshima]] **29: [[Fukuyama, Hiroshima]]
*30:The ''banzuke'' for the November tournament is released. Harumafuji occupies the top position of Yokozuna 1 East for the first time in six tournaments.<ref name="rankings">{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/10/30/sumo/harumafuji-tops-rankings-kyushu-basho/#.WfnuiE2Wzoo|title=Harumafuji tops rankings for Kyushu Basho|date=30 October 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref> His [[Isegahama stable (2007)|Isegahama stable]]mate [[Aminishiki]] also has a reason to celebrate as he is promoted back to ''makuuchi'' after an eight tournament absence. At 39 years old he is the oldest man to be promoted to the top division since the beginning of the [[Shōwa era]] in 1926.<ref name="rankings"/> Terunofuji is demoted to ''sekiwake'', while Onosho makes his debut at ''komusubi''.<ref name="rankings"/> The only newcomer to the top division is [[Daiamami]], a [[Nihon University]] graduate.<ref name="rankings"/> Making his ''juryo'' debut is [[Takanosho]], formerly Masunosho, of [[Chiganoura stable]]. He is first wrestler from the stable since [[Masunoyama]] in 2010 to become a ''[[sekitori]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnHonbashoTopics/banzuke_topics/|title=2017 November Grand Sumo Tournament Banzuke Topics|date=October 2017|publisher=Japan Sumo Association|accessdate=31 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171030162158/http://www.sumo.or.jp/EnHonbashoTopics/banzuke_topics/|archivedate=30 October 2017}}</ref>
===November=== [[File:大相撲川崎場所 2017 (33888979592).jpg|thumb|Harumafuji]] *8: Kakuryū's stablemaster [[Sakahoko|Izutsu Oyakata]] says the ''yokozuna'' will miss the Kyūshū tournament because he has been experiencing lower back pain in addition to his previously known right leg problem. It is the fifth time this year that he has missed at least some of a tournament, and the second in a row that he will sit out entirely. Izutsu says "It would be irresponsible to compete in his current condition. We're terribly sorry."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2017/11/08/sumo/yokozuna-kakuryu-pulls-kyushu-tournament/#.WgnK5E2WyM8|title=Yokozuna Kakuryu pulls out of Kyushu tournament|date=8 November 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=13 November 2017}}</ref> *14: Harumafuji withdraws from the tournament on Day 3, on the same day as reports emerge he assaulted fellow Mongolian [[Takanoiwa]] with a beer bottle during the regional tour stop in [[Tottori, Tottori|Tottori]] on October 26. Takanoiwa pulled out ahead of this tournament with a medical certificate citing concussion and a skull base fracture.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/11/14/national/crime-legal/yokozuna-harumafuji-suspected-assaulting-fellow-wrestler-beer-bottle-report/#.WgrwSE2Wzop|title=Yokozuna Harumafuji suspected of assaulting fellow wrestler with beer bottle: report|date=14 November 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> It was alleged that Harumafuji had been drinking and struck Takanoiwa because "he did not like his attitude."<ref name="bbc">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-41982929|title=Sumo champ Harumafuji investigated over 'bottle assault'|date=14 November 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> [[Takanohana Kōji|Takanohana]], Takanoiwa's stablemaster, has reported the incident to the police, and the [[Sumo Association]] are also investigating.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/11/14/national/crime-legal/yokozuna-harumafuji-suspected-assaulting-fellow-wrestler-beer-bottle-report/#.WgsLSE2Wzoo|title=Yokozuna Harumafuji involved in drunken assault on fellow wrestler, stablemaster admits|date=14 November 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> Harumafuji told reporters after a morning training session in [[Dazaifu, Fukuoka|Dazaifu]], "as for Takanoiwa's injuries, I apologise deeply for causing trouble for stable master Takanohana, people affiliated with Takanohana stable, the Sumo Association and my stable master."<ref name="bbc"/> He visited the Fukuoka base of the [[Takanohana stable]] with his stablemaster, [[Asahifuji|Isegahama Oyakata]], but was unable to make a direct apology as Takanohana and Takanoiwa were absent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201711140035.html|title=SUMO/ Harumafuji apologizes for drunk beating of fellow wrestler|date=14 November 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> *22: Takanohana refuses to allow the Sumo Association access to Takanoiwa, saying the matter must be left to police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201711230049.html|title=SUMO/ Stablemaster rejects JSA’s request to hear from Takanoiwa|date=23 November 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> *25: Hakuhō's 40th championship is assured when, having seen his two closest pursuers [[Okinoumi]] and [[Hokutofuji]] both lose, he defeats [[Endō Shōta|Endō]] to move to an unassailable two win lead on 13–1. *26: Hakuhō wraps up the tournament by defeating Goeidō (the only other ''yokozuna'' or ''ozeki'' to complete the whole 15 days) to finish on 14–1, three wins ahead of ''maegashira'' Okinoumi, Hokutofuji, [[Tamawashi]] and [[Takakeisho]], who all finish on 11–4. It is the first time four ''maegashira'' have been runner-up in a single tournament. The Outstanding Performance prize goes to Takakeisho for defeating two ''yokozuna'' (Hakuhō's only defeat was to [[Yoshikaze]] who was ineligible for a special prize as he failed to get a majority of wins), Hokutofuji wins the Technique Prize, and the Fighting Spirit Award is shared between Okinoumi and Aminishiki. The ''juryo'' division championship is won by [[Sokokurai]] with a 14–1 record, while [[Tochihiryu]] wins the ''[[makushita]]'' championship. *27: Takanohana, whose decision to report Harumafuji's alleged assault to police and refusal to co-operate with investigators has attracted criticism, reportedly tells supporters at a post-''basho'' party that as head of the regional tour department he had a "responsibility to seek justice" no matter who the wrestler was, and that Takanoiwa's injuries are serious. Meanwhile, Hakuhō says that he wants to see both Harumafuji and Takanoiwa back on the ''dohyo'' as soon as possible, and that he will tell police exactly what he saw in order to rid the sumo world of "the pus."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/11/27/national/hakuho-says-will-tell-truth-fellow-wrestlers-assault-takanoiwa-rid-sumo-world-pus/#.Wh2Kz--nGUk|title=Signs of strife within sumo association emerge ahead police probe of alleged assault|date=27 November 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> *27: The [[Yokozuna Deliberation Council]] calls for "extremely harsh punishment" of Harumafuji, which could entail suspension from tournaments, a recommendation to retire, or dismissal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/11/28/national/crime-legal/sumo-advisory-council-recommends-extremely-harsh-punishment-harumafuji/#.Wh2He02Wzoo|title=Sumo advisory council recommends ‘extremely harsh punishment’ for Harumafuji|date=28 November 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> *28: Japan Sumo Association chairman [[Hokutoumi|Hakkaku Oyakata]] apologises to [[Daichi Suzuki]] of the {{Interlanguage link multi|Japan Sport Agency|ja|3=スポーツ庁}} for the Harumafuji assault scandal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0004094465|title=Sumo boss apologizes for assault scandal|date=28 November 2017|publisher=The Japan News|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> *29: Harumafuji announces his retirement at a press conference. He does not go into details about the alleged assault on Takanoiwa, but says, "I had heard that he was lacking in manners and civility and thought it was my duty as a senior wrestler to correct and teach him. But I went too far."<ref name="guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/nov/29/sumo-grand-champion-harumafuji-felled-by-assault-allegations|title=Sumo grand champion Harumafuji felled by assault allegations|last=McCurry|first=Justin|date=29 November 2017|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref> His stablemaster says that Harumafuji has "caused great trouble" for the Sumo Association and sumo fans, and as a ''yokozuna'' he must take responsibility.<ref name="guardian"/> *30: An interim report issued by the Sumo Association's investigative committee says that the October 25 incident occurred at a party to celebrate graduates of [[Tottori Johoku High School]], which include [[Terunofuji]] and [[Takanoiwa]]. The three Mongolian ''yokozuna'', [[Harumafuji]], [[Kakuryu]] and [[Hakuho]] were all present. Hakuho criticized Takanoiwa for previous disrespectful behavior at a restaurant in September. After the group moved on to another bar to continue drinking, Hakuho lectured Takanoiwa and Terunofuji on how they must never forget what they learned in their school days. Harumafuji told Takanoiwa to pay attention, at which point Takanoiwa, who was looking at his mobile phone, grinned and said he had just received an e-mail from his girlfriend. Infuriated, Harumafuji slapped Takanoiwa several times around the face to get him to apologize to Hakuho and when Takanoiwa refused to do so, grabbed a karaoke machine remote control and hit Takanoiwa over the head with it several times, which eventually required stitches. The report says that the beer bottle widely cited in early media reports was in fact a champagne bottle which slipped out of Harumafuji's hands before he could use it to hit Takanoiwa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201712010023.html|title=JSA: Harumafuji beat Takanoiwa to force apology to Hakuho|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|date=1 December 2017|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
===December=== *1: Hakuhō and his stablemaster [[Chikubayama|Miyagino]] are severely reprimanded by the Sumo Association for Hakuhō's inappropriate behavior during his ''yūshō'' interview, when he called for Harumafuji and Takanoiwa to return to the ring and led the crowd in "[[ten thousand years|banzai]]" cheers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/12/01/national/takanohana-cooperate-sumo-associations-probe-harumafuji-assault-case/#.WiGTSU2Wzoo|title=Takanohana to cooperate with sumo association’s probe into Harumafuji assault case|date=1 December 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref> *The winter tour visits the following locations: **3: [[Omura, Nagasaki]] **4: [[Goto, Nagasaki]] **6: [[Nogata, Fukuoka]] **7: [[Usa, Oita]] **8: [[Miyazaki, Miyazaki]] **9: [[Kumamoto, Kumamoto]] **10: [[Kagoshima, Kagoshima]] **11: [[Kitakyushu, Fukuoka]] **13-14: [[Miyakojima, Okinawa]] **16-17: [[Ginowan, Okinawa]]
*11: Tottori police conclude their investigation and turn the case over to prosecutors. Harumafuji's lawyers respond to criticism that he did not directly apologize to Takanoiwa during his retirement press conference by saying that Harumafuji was nervous, and "wholeheartedly offer an apology to all on (our client's) behalf."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201712110035.html|title=Harumafuji's next bout likely to be in court rather than ring|date=11 December 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> *20: Hakuhō and Kakuryū are docked one and half month's and one month's salary respectively by the Sumo Association and criticized for not doing enough to prevent the beating incident at which both were present. The Sumo Association also accepts the resignation of Isegahama as a director, and reveals that Takanoiwa finally spoke to the crisis committee investigating the affair on December 19, but the wrestler said that he did nothing discourteous that would cause Harumafuji to attack him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201712200044.html|title=Yokozuna Hakuho, Kakuryu docked pay over beating|date=20 December 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> Chairman Hakkaku is also foregoing his salary for the last three months of his term.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/12/20/national/harumafuji-stablemaster-quits-jsa-board-while-hakuho-and-kakuryu-get-pay-cuts/#.WjqQ502Wzoo|title=Harumafuji’s stablemaster quits JSA board while Hakuho and Kakuryu slapped with pay cuts|date=20 December 2017|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> *28: Harumafuji is given a summary indictment over the Takanoiwa assault, meaning he is likely to be fined rather than face a court trial.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-42502080|title=Japan sumo champion Harumafuji charged with assault|date=28 December 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> An emergency meeting of the Sumo Association's board of directors recommends that Takanohana be dismissed as a director and demoted two rungs in the hierarchy, to take responsibility for the Takanoiwa incident which occurred under his watch as regional tour director. The recommendation must be formalized at another meeting on January 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201712280045.html|title=JSA to oust Takanohana as director over beating scandal|date=28 December 2017|publisher=Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref>
==Deaths== *Jan 25: Former [[makushita]] 37 [[Jun Izumida|Musashiumi]], also a pro wrestler, aged 51, of a heart attack. *Jan 31: Former komusubi [[Tokitenku]] (see January entry) *Apr 27: Former yokozuna [[Sadanoyama Shinmatsu|Sadanoyama]], aged 79, of pneumonia. (see April entry)
==See also== *[[Glossary of sumo terms]] *[[List of active sumo wrestlers]] *[[List of years in sumo]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Years in sumo}}
[[Category:Years in sumo]] [[Category:2017 in sports|Sumo]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox football club | clubname = Audax Italiano | image = AudaxItalianoBadge.png | fullname = Audax Club Sportivo Italiano, SADP {{cite web|url=http://anfp.cl/portal1a.php?equipo%3D2 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091125181958/http://www.anfp.cl/portal1a.php?equipo=2 |archivedate=2009-11-25 |df= }} | nickname = ''Los Tanos'', ''Los Itálicos'', ''Audinos'' | founded = 30 November 1910 | ground = [[Estadio Bicentenario de La Florida]]
[[La Florida, Chile]]| | capacity = 12,000 | chairman = Lorenzo Antillo | manager = [[Juan José Ribera]] | league = [[Primera División de Chile|Campeonato Nacional]] | season = [[2017 Chilean Primera División|2017 Transición]] | position = 5th | website = http://www.audaxitaliano.cl/ | current = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=1C9E1C|body1=1C9E1C|rightarm1=1C9E1C|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=1C9E1C | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=1C9E1C|socks2=FFFFFF }} '''Audax Club Sportivo Italiano''' ({{IPA-es|ˈauðaks itaˈljano}}) is a Chilean [[Association football|football]] club based in [[La Florida, Chile|La Florida]]. Founded in 1910, it plays in the [[Primera División de Chile|Campeonato Nacional]] and has spent most of its history in the top tier of Chilean football. Audax has been national champions four times, joint sixth alongside [[C.D. Magallanes|Magallanes]]. The club also achieved two [[Copa Chile]] runners-up in 1981 and 1988. The club had their first major success in 1936, when they won the league tournament. During the 1940s, Audax won two leagues in 1946 and 1948, reaching a fourth in 1957. ==History== The club was founded by Italian residents in Santiago, on November 30, 1910 as '''Audax Club Ciclista Italiano''' in the Alberto Caffi's hat store, and was originally focused in [[cycling]]. As [[Association football|football]] developed quickly in Santiago, in 1917 the club begun participating in that sport, and in 1922, when the popularity of football increased within Audax's supporters, the club changed its name to '''Audax Club Sportivo Italiano'''. In January 2007, the club was transformed into a limited liability corporation, and changed its name to '''Audax Italiano La Florida''', adding the name of the ''comuna'' in which it's always been located. The club has always been a regular protagonist in Chilean football, but had never been able to participate in any major international competition until 2007, when they played in the [[Copa Libertadores]]. As a club founded by immigrants, it has a special rivalry with the other immigrant clubs [[Unión Española]] (founded by Spaniards) and [[Palestino]] (founded by Palestinian Arabs). ==Honours== ===Domestic Competitions=== *'''[[Primera División de Chile]] **'''Winners (4): [[1936 Primera División de Chile|1936]], [[1946 Primera División de Chile|1946]], [[1948 Primera División de Chile|1948]], [[1957 Primera División de Chile|1957]] **''Runner-up (8): 1934, 1935, 1938, 1940, 1944, 1947, 1951, 2006 C *'''[[Primera B de Chile]] **''Runner-Up (1): 1995 *'''Ligulla Pre-Sudamericana **'''Winners (1): 2007 *[[Copa Chile]] **''Runner-up (2): 1981, [[1998 Copa Apertura|1998]] *'''[[Campeonato de Apertura (Chile)|Campeonato de Apertura]]: **'''Winners (1): 1941 ==Performance in CONMEBOL competitions== *'''[[Copa Libertadores]]: 2 appearances''' ::[[2007 Copa Libertadores|2007]]: Group Stage ::[[2008 Copa Libertadores|2008]]: Group Stage *'''[[Copa Sudamericana]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[2007 Copa Sudamericana|2007]]: Second Preliminary Round *'''[[Copa CONMEBOL]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[1998 Copa CONMEBOL|1998]]: First Round ==Records== *'''Largest margin of victory:''' ::In Primera División matches: 9–2 vs. [[Club Deportivo Universidad Católica|Universidad Católica]] in 1945 ::In Copa Chile matches: 13–0 vs. Juventud Varsovia in 2010 ::In international matches: 3–1 [[Alianza Lima]] in 2007 *'''Largest margin of defeat:''' ::In Primera División matches: 1–7 vs. [[Colo-Colo]] in 1939 & 0–6 vs. [[Santiago Wanderers]] in 1993 ::In international matches: 1–4 vs. [[Sportivo Luqueño]] in 2008 *'''Longest win streak:''' 24 games in 2007 *'''Most goals scored in international play:''' [[Rodolfo Moya]] & [[Carlos Villanueva (footballer)|Carlos Villanueva]] (3 goals) *'''Most goals scored in Primera División:''' Carlos Tello (101 goals) *'''Most goals scored in one season in Primera División:''' [[José Luis Díaz]] (23 goals in 1999) *'''Most goals scored in two short tournaments:''' [[Carlos Villanueva (footballer)|Carlos Villanueva]] (30 goals in 2007) ==Players== ===Current squad=== {{Audax Italiano squad|format=table}} ===2018 Winter Transfers=== ====In==== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no= 9|nat=ARG|pos=FW|name=[[Jonathan Carlos Herrera|Jonathan Herrera]]|other=from [[Ferro Carril Oeste]]}} {{Fs player|no=11|nat=PAR|pos=FW|name=[[Cristian Bogado]]|other=from [[Unión Comercio]]}} {{Fs mid}} {{Fs player|no=12|nat=CHI|pos=GK|name=[[Eyrin Sanhueza]]|other=back from [[Deportes Colchagua]]}} {{Fs player|no=18|nat=ARG|pos=MF|name=[[Darío Bottinelli]]|other=from [[América de Cali]]}} {{Fs end}} ====Out==== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no=7|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Bryan Carrasco]]|other= to [[Tiburones Rojos de Veracruz|Veracruz]]}} {{Fs player|no=10|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Joe Abrigo]]|other=loaned to [[Tiburones Rojos de Veracruz|Veracruz]]}} {{Fs player|no=11|nat=PAR|pos=FW|name=[[Cristian Bogado]]|other=Released}} {{Fs mid}} {{Fs player|no=13|nat=URU|pos=FW|name=[[Sebastián Abreu]]|other=to [[Deportes Magallanes|Magallanes]]}} {{Fs player|no=22|nat=CHI|pos=GK|name=[[Nicolás Peric]]|other=to [[Rangers de Talca|Rangers]]}} {{Fs player|no=24|nat=CHI|pos=DF|name=[[Jorge Faúndez]]|other=loaned to [[Deportes Puerto Montt]]}} {{Fs end}} ==Managers== {{col-begin-small}} revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox hockey team | team = EHC Lustenau | colour = Blue | colour text = White | logo = EHC Lustenau.png | logosize = 140px | city = [[Lustenau]], [[Austria]] | league = '''[[Inter-National League]]'''
[[Austrian National League]] | conference = | division = | founded = {{Start date and age|1970}} | arena = Rheinhalle Lustenau | colours = Yellow, Green | coach = | GM = | name1 = | dates1 = | name2 = | dates2 = | website = http://www.ehc-lustenau.at }} '''Eishockey Club Lustenau''', commonly referred to as '''EHC Lustenau''' or simply '''Lustenau''', is an ice hockey team in [[Lustenau]], [[Austria]]. They play in the [[Inter-National League]], the second level of [[ice hockey in Austria]] and [[Slovenia]]. ==History== The club was founded as EHC Lustenau in 1970. In 2000, the club was renamed Gunz EHC Lustenau. They took on their present name, EHC Oberschieder Lustenau in 2005. ==Achievements== * [[Austrian National League]] champion: 1974, 1978, 1982, 1984, 1992, 1997, 2006, 2009. ==External links== *[http://www.ehc-lustenau.at Official website] {{de icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lustenau}} [[Category:Ice hockey clubs established in 1970]] [[Category:Ice hockey teams in Austria]] [[Category:Alpenliga teams]] [[Category:Inter-National League teams]] [[Category:Austrian National League teams]] [[Category:1970 establishments in Austria]] {{Austria-sport-team-stub}} {{Europe-icehockey-team-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Stride-q210c.jpg|thumb|right|An elliptical machine, a type of exercise machine]] An '''exercise machine''' is any [[machine]] used for physical [[exercise]]. These range from simple spring-like devices to computerized electromechanical rides to recirculating-stream swimming pools. Most exercise machines incorporate an ergometer. An '''ergometer''' is an apparatus for measuring the [[mechanical work|work]] a person exerts while exercising as used in training or [[cardiac stress tests]] or other medical tests.
==Resistance machines== === Weight machines === {{Main|Weight machine}} Weight machines use gravity as the primary source of resistance, and a combination of [[simple machine]]s to convey that resistance, to the person using the machine. Each of the simple machines (pulley, lever, wheel, incline) changes the [[mechanical advantage]] of the overall machine relative to the weight.
===Other kinds of resistance machines=== *kBox * [[Friction]] machines * [[Spring (device)|Spring]]-loaded machines (such as [[Bowflex]]) * Fan-loaded machines * Fluid-loaded machines * [[Bullworker]] * Hydraulic equipment * [[Whole body vibration]] * [[Outdoor gym]] * [[Pneumatic exercise equipment]] * [[Soloflex]] * [[Precor StretchTrainer|StretchTrainer]]
==Endless-path machines== [[File:Gymnasticon.png|thumb|The [[Gymnasticon]], an early exercise machine resembling a stationary bicycle]]
===Stationary bicycles=== * [[Exercise bicycle]]
===Running/walking machines=== *[[Treadmill]] *[[Elliptical trainer]]
===Elliptical machines=== Ellipticals (elliptical machines) are a combination of stair-climbing and a treadmill. Generally it contains two tracks upon which the user stands; when he or she moves his or her legs, they describe an elliptical motion (hence the machine name). Some ellipticals have magnetic resistance controls that add difficulty to doing the motion.
===Glider machines=== This machine allows the user to stand on two separate foot pedals and use their own muscles to create the movement. The stabilized movement can be likened to that of a "swing set" for each leg.
===Climbing machines=== Also named stair-climbing machines, they work the user's legs as he/she pumps pedals up and down, much like climbing stairs. Some climbing machines have handles to push and pull to exercise the whole body. <!--===Skiing machines===--->
===Rowing machines=== [[Indoor rower|Rowing machines]], also named rowers, simulate the body movements of using a rowing boat.
===Skiing machines=== [[NordicTrack]]
==See also== *[[Chin-up bar]] *[[Exercise equipment]] *[[Sports medicine]] *[[Physical therapy|Rehabilitation]] *[[Statics]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Exercise Machine}} [[Category:Exercise equipment]] [[Category:Strength training]]

Soccer Matters with Glenn Davis
Wednesdays 7-9 p.m. [[Central Time Zone|CT]] on [[KFNC|ESPN 97.5 FM]]{{cite web|title=On Air Schedule - ESPN 97.5|url=http://www.espn975.com/on-air-schedule/|website=ESPN 97.5|accessdate=December 30, 2017}}
'''Television:'''
[[Houston Dynamo#Television|Houston Dynamo game broadcasts]] on [[KUBE-TV|KUBE 57]] (play-by-play announcer){{cite web|title=KUBE TV, Channel 57, to televise two Dynamo matches in 2016|url=https://www.houstondynamo.com/post/2016/04/13/kube-tv-channel-57-televise-two-dynamo-matches-2016|website=Houston Dynamo|accessdate=December 30, 2017|archivedate=April 13, 2016|language=en|date=13 April 2016}} | credits = '''Play-by-Play Announcer:'''
