==30 November 2006 (Thursday)== *[[2006 Asian Games|Asian Games]] **[[Baseball at the 2006 Asian Games|Baseball]] – {{flagicon|TPE}} [[Chinese Taipei at the 2006 Asian Games|Chinese Taipei]] (Taiwan) 4–2 {{flag|South Korea}}. The Taiwanese use three [[home run]]s to strike first in the gold medal chase. **[[Table Tennis at the 2006 Asian Games|Table Tennis]] ***Men (Team): {{flagicon|TPE}} [[Chinese Taipei at the 2006 Asian Games|Chinese Taipei]] (Taiwan) and {{flag|Singapore}} advance to the quarterfinals. ****Quarterfinal Matches: *****{{flagu|China}} 3–0 {{flag|Qatar}} *****{{flagicon|TPE}} [[Chinese Taipei at the 2006 Asian Games|Chinese Taipei]] (Taiwan) 3–0 {{flag|Vietnam}} *****{{flag|Hong Kong}} 3–2 {{flagu|Japan}} *****{{flag|Singapore}} 0–3 {{flag|South Korea}} ***Women (Team): {{flagicon|PRK}}[[DPR Korea]] and {{flagu|India}} advance to the quarterfinals ****Quarterfinal Matches: *****{{flagicon|PRK}} [[DPR Korea]] 3–0 {{flag|Thailand}} *****{{flag|Hong Kong}} 1–3 {{flag|Singapore}} *****{{flag|South Korea}} 3–0 {{flagu|India}} *****{{flagu|Japan}} 0–3 {{flagu|China}} *[[Cricket]]: [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] batsman [[Mohammad Yousuf (cricketer, born 1974)|Mohammad Yousuf]] breaks [[Viv Richards]]' record for runs in [[test cricket]] in a calendar year in a match against the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]].http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,20848685-23212,00.html *[[Football (American)|American football]]: **[[College football|College]]: [[Mid-American Conference|MAC]] Championship at [[Ford Field|Detroit]]: ***[[Central Michigan Chippewas football|Central Michigan]] 31, [[Ohio Bobcats football|Ohio]] 10: The Chippewas win their first outright MAC title. **[[National Football League|NFL]] Week 13 Thursday Night Game: [[Cincinnati Bengals]] 13, [[Baltimore Ravens]] 7. [[T. J. Houshmandzadeh]]'s 40-yard catch of a flea-flicker pass from [[Carson Palmer]] prevented the Ravens from clinching the [[AFC North]]. *[[Football (soccer)]]: [[2006–07 UEFA Cup]] Matchday 4. Clubs that have qualified today for the Round of 32 are in '''bold.''' **Group E: [[AS Nancy|Nancy]] 3–0 [[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]][[#fn1|1]] **Group E: [[Wisła Kraków]] 3–1 [[FC Basel]] **Group F: [[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]] 0–2 [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] **Group F: [[FK Austria Wien|Austria Vienna]] 0–1 [[AC Sparta Praha|Sparta Prague]] **Group G: [[FK Mladá Boleslav|Mladá Boleslav]] 0–0 [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] **Group G: '''[[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]]''' 0–0 [[FC Rapid Bucureşti|Rapid Bucharest]] **Group H: [[Celta de Vigo|Celta Vigo]] 1–0 [[Fenerbahçe SK|Fenerbahçe]] **Group H: [[Eintracht Frankfurt]] 0–0 [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] ''{{note|1|Note 1}}: '' The match was suspended after 80 minutes of play at 3–0 due to crowd trouble. Feyenoord fans who gathered tickets for the match in an illegal way and others who were held at the stadium by the police were rioting during the whole match. After a 20-minute break, the match was finished.
==29 November 2006 (Wednesday)== *[[2006 Asian Games|Asian Games]] **[[Table Tennis at the 2006 Asian Games|Table Tennis]] ***Team-Men – {{flagu|China}}, {{flagu|Japan}}, {{flagicon|KOR}}[[Korea]], {{flag|Qatar}}, {{flag|Hong Kong}}, and {{flag|Vietnam}} all advance to the quarterfinals. ***Team-Women – {{flag|Hong Kong}}, {{flagu|China}}, {{flagicon|KOR}}[[Korea]], {{flagu|Japan}}, {{flag|Thailand}}, and {{flag|Singapore}} all advance to the quarterfinals. *[[College basketball|College Basketball (American)]]: For the second time in less than a week, the top team in the [[Associated Press|AP]] NCAA Men's Division I poll came up on the losing side of the score, as this week's #1 team, [[Ohio State Buckeyes|Ohio State]] was beaten by #6 [[North Carolina Tar Heels|North Carolina]] 98–89 [[Dean Smith Center|in the "Dean Dome"]]. *[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: [[2006–07 UEFA Cup]] Matchday 4. Clubs that clinched advancement to the round of 32 today are in '''bold'''. **Group A: [[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]] 1–4 [[AJ Auxerre]] **Group A: [[A.S. Livorno Calcio|Livorno]] 1–1 '''[[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]]''' **Group B: '''[[FC Dinamo București|Dinamo Bucharest]]''' 2–1 [[Bayer Leverkusen]] **Group B: [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] 2–1 [[Club Brugge]] **Group C: [[Grasshopper Club Zürich|Grasshoppers]] 0–4 '''[[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]]''' **Group C: '''[[AZ Alkmaar]]''' 2–2 [[FC Slovan Liberec|Slovan Liberec]] **Group D: [[RC Lens|Lens]] 1–2 [[Parma F.C.|Parma]] **Group D: [[CA Osasuna|Osasuna]] 3–1 [[Odense BK|Odense]] *General news: **[[FIFA]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20061210011326/http://www.fifa.com/en/media/index/0,1369,126515,00.html?articleid=126515 announces its three-player shortlists] for the [[FIFA World Player of the Year|2006 World Player of the Year awards]]: ***Men: [[Fabio Cannavaro]] ({{fb|ITA}}), [[Ronaldinho]] ({{fb|BRA}}), [[Zinedine Zidane]] ({{fb|FRA}}) ***Women: [[Kristine Lilly]] ({{fbw|USA}}), [[Renate Lingor]] ({{fbw|GER}}), [[Marta Vieira da Silva|Marta]] ({{fbw|BRA}}) **[[José Manuel Esnal]] who promoted with [[Levante UD]] towards [[La Liga]] in the 2005–06 season will replace [[Félix Sarriugarte]] as the manager of [[Athletic Bilbao]]. **[[Gimnàstic de Tarragona]] appoints [[Paco Flores]] as their new manager. Flores who was also manager of [[RCD Espanyol de Barcelona|RCD Espanyol]] and [[Real Zaragoza]] replaces [[Luis Ángel César Sampedro]], who was fired earlier this week. *[[Rugby union]]: **[[Andy Robinson]] resigns as manager of the [[England national rugby union team]] after his team lost eight out of the last nine matches he managed the team.
==28 November 2006 (Tuesday)== *[[2006 Asian Games|Asian Games]] **[[Volleyball at the 2006 Asian Games|Volleyball]] – {{flagicon|TPE}}[[Chinese Taipei at the 2006 Asian Games|Chinese Taipei]] (Taiwan), {{flagicon|KWT}}[[Kuwait]], {{flagicon|BHR}} [[Bahrain]], and {{flagicon|LBN}} [[Lebanon]] advance to the second round. *[[Cricket]] – [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistani]] [[cricketer]] '''[[Mohammad Yousuf (cricketer, born 1974)|Mohammad Yousuf]]''' becomes the first to score 8 [[test cricket|test]] [[Century (cricket)|centuries]] in a [[calendar year]] during the third test of the [[West Indian cricket team in Pakistan in 2006–07|West Indies tour of Pakistan]]. *[[Equestrianism|Equestrian]]: **The parents of [[Albert Zoer]] who own his horse [[Okidoki]] reject a €4,000,000 bid on the 10-year-old horse. Zoer already won several Grand-Prix events with Okidoki and they were part of the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] team that became World Champions in [[Aachen]] in 2006. Owner Mr. Zoer told the press he prefers his son's career over the money. *[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]]: **Breaststroke specialist [[Madelon Baans]] ends her career at the age of 29 to concentrate on her post-sport career. Baans is 49 time Dutch national champion, current Dutch national record holder at the 100m breaststroke in either the 25- and 50m pools. During the 2004 European Championships in [[Madrid]], she won the bronze medal as being part of the 4 × 100 m medley, in the same year she reached the final at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] on the same discipline. *[[2010 Winter Olympics]]: **[[Skicross]] will likely be added to the Olympic schedule as of the [[Vancouver]] Olympics in 2010 after the Executive Board voted in favour of the sport. The inclusion of skicross must also be approved by the Vancouver Olympic Committee for the sport to be officially part of the sport program. Other events that were up for inclusion were rejected. These events included: [[Biathlon]] mixed relay, mixed [[curling]], team [[alpine skiing]], team [[bobsleigh]], team [[skeleton (sport)|skeleton]], team [[luge]] and women's [[ski jumping]].
==27 November 2006 (Monday)== *[[2006 Asian Games|Asian Games]]: **[[Volleyball at the 2006 Asian Games|Volleyball]] – {{flagicon|UAE}} United Arab Emirates and {{flagicon|HKG}} Hong Kong advance to the second round. *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]] [[Basketball]]: **The top teams in the Eastern and Western Conferences met in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]], as the [[Orlando Magic]] defeated the [[Utah Jazz]], 88–75. [[Dwight Howard]] and [[Carlos Boozer]] led their respective teams with 21 points each, but Howard had 16 rebounds as well. The Magic out-rebounded the Jazz, 45–36. *[[Cricket]]: [[English cricket team in Australia in 2006–07|England in Australia]]: **{{cr|AUS}} wins the opening [[The Ashes|Ashes]] [[Test cricket|Test]] in [[Brisbane]], defeating {{cr|ENG}} by 277 runs at the [[Brisbane Cricket Ground|Gabba]]. Australian captain [[Ricky Ponting]] is named Player of the Match for his score of 196 in the First Innings. [http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/ausveng/engine/current/match/249222.html (Scorecard)] *[[Football (American)]]: **[[National Football League|NFL]] [[Monday Night Football]]: ***[[Seattle Seahawks]] 34, [[Green Bay Packers]] 24. [[Shaun Alexander]] rushed 40 times for 201 yards, becoming the third player in NFL history to do so, and [[Matt Hasselbeck]] threw for three second half touchdowns in the first Seahawks game played in a Seattle snowstorm. **[[College football|College]]: ***[[Alabama Crimson Tide football|Alabama]] fired head coach [[Mike Shula]]. [[Joe Kines]], former [[Arkansas Razorbacks|Arkansas]] coach, will serve as the team's coach in their bowl game. ***[[Michigan State Spartans football|Michigan State]] names [[Cincinnati Bearcats|Cincinnati]] head coach [[Mark Dantonio]] as their new coach. The Bearcats then announce defensive coordinator Pat Narduzzi will coach the team in their bowl game. ***[[Iowa State Cyclones|Iowa State]] reaches into the [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] and names [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]] assistant [[Gene Chizik]] as their new coach. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **The Golden Ball, the prize awarded to the [[European Footballer of the Year]], goes to [[Fabio Cannavaro]] of [[Real Madrid]]. Cannavaro was the captain of [[Italy national football team|Italy]] during the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] where his team became World Champion. Cannavaro gained 173 points, with [[Gianluigi Buffon]] (124) and [[Thierry Henry]] (121) following in second and third place. He is the first defender to win the award since [[Matthias Sammer]] in 1996. **[[Branko Oblak]] resigns as the manager of [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]]. Oblak led the Slovenians since 2004. **In Spain two [[La Liga]] managers were sacked due to achieving weak results in the competition. [[Félix Sarriugarte]] only won 8 points in 12 games at [[Athletic Bilbao]], while [[Luis Ángel César Sampedro]] was in the bottom position with his team [[Gimnàstic de Tarragona]]. **[[RKC Waalwijk]] sacks their manager [[Adrie Koster]]. RKC is currently in 18th and last position of the [[Eredivisie 2006/2007|Eredivisie]]. *[[Ice hockey]]: The [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s [[Chicago Blackhawks]] fire head coach [[Trent Yawney]] and name former star [[Denis Savard]] as his replacement. *[[Tennis]]: **[[Thiemo de Bakker]] and [[Antal van der Duim]] are suspended for a month by the [[Koninklijke Nederlandse Lawn Tennis Bond|Dutch Tennis Federation]], because the two did not follow the commitments made between them and the federation. They were supposed to fly back home, but played three tournaments in [[Israel]] instead. De Bakker reached the final in one of these tournaments.
==26 November 2006 (Sunday)== *[[2006 Asian Games|Asian Games]] **[[Basketball at the 2006 Asian Games|Basketball]]: {{flagicon|UZB}} Uzbekistan, {{flagicon|SYR}} Syria, and {{flagicon|KAZ}} Kazakhstan all advance to the second round of the tournament by winning their respective groups. **[[Volleyball at the 2006 Asian Games|Volleyball]]: {{flagicon|KSA}} Saudi Arabia and {{flagicon|MAC}} Macau advance to the second round of the tournament. *[[Auto racing]]: [[2006-07 A1 Grand Prix of Nations, Malaysia]]: **[[Neel Jani]] finishes in first position of the sprint race, beating [[Nico Hülkenberg]] and [[Jonny Reid]]. Hülkenberg however, wins the main race later in the day by finishing in front of [[Robbie Kerr]] and [[Nicolas Lapierre]]. *[[Cycling]]: During the [[Six Days of Ghent]] current world champion at the [[madison (cycling)|madison]] [[Isaac Gálvez]] was involved in a serious crash in which he received serious injuries. He was rushed to a nearby hospital. While being rushed there, he died as a result of his injuries. The race was immediately stopped and no winners were announced. *[[Football (American)]] **[[College football]]: Two head coaches were given their walking papers as [[NC State Wolfpack football|North Carolina State]]'s [[Chuck Amato]] and [[Arizona State Sun Devils|Arizona State]]'s [[Dirk Koetter]] were fired. ([http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/sports/16104233.htm Charlotte Observer via San Jose Mercury News]{{dead link|date=August 2015}}) **[[National Football League|NFL]] Week 12 Sunday games: ***[[Minnesota Vikings]] 31, [[Arizona Cardinals]] 26. Chester Taylor's 136 yards rushing was part of the Vikings' win. ***[[Washington Redskins]] 17, [[Carolina Panthers]] 13. Redskins quarterback [[Jason Campbell]] gets his first NFL win on a 66-yard touchdown pass to [[Chris Cooley (American football)|Chris Cooley]] late in the fourth quarter. ***[[Cincinnati Bengals]] 30, [[Cleveland Browns]] 0. The Bengals pitch a shutout for the first time since December 3, 1989, against the Browns. ***[[New York Jets]] 26, [[Houston Texans]] 11. [[Chad Pennington]] threw for 289 yards in the Jet's win. ***[[Buffalo Bills]] 27, [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] 24. Rian Lindell's 42-yard field goal as time expired gave the Bills their second straight come-from-behind win. ***[[New Orleans Saints]] 31, [[Atlanta Falcons]] 13. [[Michael Vick]] runs for 166 yards but completes only nine passes, then [[finger (gesture)|flips off]] booing fans while leaving the field. He later apologizes for the gesture. Meanwhile, Ryan Copper's 48-yard catch of a "[[Hail Mary pass]]" from [[Drew Brees]] to end the first half stunned the Falcons. ***[[Baltimore Ravens]] 27, [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] 0. The Ravens sack [[Ben Roethlisberger]] nine times and intercept him twice. ***[[St. Louis Rams]] 20, [[San Francisco 49ers]] 17. [[Marc Bulger]] saved the day for the Rams with a game-winning five-yard TD pass ti Kevin Curtis with 27 seconds left. ***[[San Diego Chargers]] 21, [[Oakland Raiders]] 14. For the fourth week in a row, [[LaDainian Tomlinson]] leads the Chargers on a second-half comeback. This time, Tomlinson runs for two touchdowns and throws a third. ***[[New England Patriots]] 17, [[Chicago Bears]] 13: In a game with nine turnovers, [[Asante Samuel]]'s third interception ends Chicago's comeback attempt. ***[[Tennessee Titans]] 24, [[New York Giants]] 21. The Giants lead 21–0 with 10 minutes left. But [[Vince Young]] throws two touchdown passes and runs in a third score to tie the game. A [[Pacman Jones]] interception in the last minute sets up [[Rob Bironas]]' game-winning 49-yard field goal. ***[[Indianapolis Colts]] 45, [[Philadelphia Eagles]] 21. [[Joseph Addai]] ties a Colts record with four rushing touchdowns. **In off-the-field news: ***The [[Denver Broncos]], searching for a kick start to a struggling offense, have replaced [[Jake Plummer]] at quarterback with rookie [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] for next Sunday night's game against Seattle. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[Slavoljub Muslin]] is re-appointed at the manager of [[K.S.C. Lokeren Oost-Vlaanderen|SC Lokeren]] where he decided to leave the club in December 2005 to manage [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow]] where he was fired in October 2006. Muslin replaces [[Ariel Jacobs]]. *[[Golf]]: [[Australian Masters|MasterCard Masters]]: **[[Justin Rose]] wins his third career win at the [[2007 European Tour]] finishing 12 under par and two strokes in front of Australians [[Greg Chalmers]] and [[Richard Green (golfer)|Richard Green]]. *[[Team handball|Handball]]: [[2006 Møbelringen Cup]]: **[[Norway women's national handball team|Norway]] defeats [[Russia women's national handball team|Russia]] 29–26 in the final match of the tournament and wins the tournament with the maximum score of six points. *[[Rugby union]]: [[2006 Autumn internationals]] **[[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] 61–17 [[Pacific Islanders rugby union team|Pacific Islanders]]. Ireland give their historic home of [[Lansdowne Road]] a fitting sendoff in the last international rugby match before a two-year redevelopment project to create a modern 50,000-seat stadium. *[[Squash (sport)|Squash]], [[2006 Women's World Open Squash Championship]], final: **[[Nicol David]] {{flagicon|MAS}} 1–9, 9–7, 3–9, 9–5, 9–2 {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Natalie Grinham]] – David successfully defends her title. *[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]]: [[Mark Warnecke]], current world champion on the 50m breaststroke announces his retirement in sports at the age of 36. Warnecke, who won a bronze medal at the [[1996 Summer Olympics]] was unable to qualify for the upcoming World Championships before taking his decision.
==25 November 2006 (Saturday)== * [[Basketball]]: Men's [[College basketball]]: [[Kansas Jayhawks|Kansas]], ranked #12 in the [[Associated Press|AP]] poll, upset the defending national champion (and #1 team) [[Florida Gators|Florida]], 82–80 in overtime at [[Las Vegas]]. * [[Canadian football|Football (Canadian)]]: [[Canadian Interuniversity Sport]] national championship ([[Vanier Cup]]): **(2) [[Laval Rouge et Or]] 13, (4) [[Saskatchewan Huskies]] 8. Laval wins their third Vanier Cup in four years, even though the Huskies were the first team to play the Vanier Cup at home under the new conference-rotation arrangement. *[[College football|Football (U.S. College)]]: [[Associated Press|AP]] NCAA Division I-A Top 25: **(3) [[USC Trojans football|Southern California]] 44, (6) [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] 24. The Trojans win moves them one step closer to meeting [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]] in the [[BCS National Championship Game]]. A win against their crosstown rival [[UCLA Bruins|UCLA]] next week will all but assure them of a visit [[University of Phoenix Stadium|to Glendale, Arizona]] January 8. **(4) [[Florida Gators football|Florida]] 21, [[Florida State Seminoles|Florida State]] 14. The Gators escape with a win in their state rivalry. **[[South Florida Bulls football|South Florida]] 24, (7) [[West Virginia Mountaineers|West Virginia]] 19. The Bulls stun the Mountaineers [[Mountaineer Field at Milan Puskar Stadium|at home]] with this major upset, knocking West Virginia out of national championship contention. **(8) [[Louisville Cardinals|Louisville]] 48, [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pittsburgh]] 24 **(12) [[Boise State Broncos football|Boise State]] 38, [[University of Nevada, Reno|Nevada]] 7. The Broncos complete a perfect regular season, all but assuring them of becoming the second team outside of the BCS conferences to play in a BCS bowl game. **(13) [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] 27, [[Oklahoma State Cowboys|Oklahoma State]] 21. With this win in the [[Bedlam Series]], the [[Sooner Schooner]] now travels to [[Arrowhead Stadium|Kansas City]] next Saturday against old rival Nebraska in the Big 12 Championship. **(15) [[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] 38, [[Syracuse Orange football|Syracuse]] 7 **[[Georgia Bulldogs football|Georgia]] 15, (16) [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets|Georgia Tech]] 12. This is Georgia's sixth straight win for the Governor's Cup. **(17) [[Virginia Tech Hokies football|Virginia Tech]] 17, [[Virginia Cavaliers|Virginia]] 0 **(19) [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]] 17, [[Kentucky Wildcats|Kentucky]] 12. For the 22nd straight time, the Wildcats fall to the Vols, the second longest losing streak by one school against another. Notre Dame's 42-game streak against [[Navy Midshipmen football|Navy]] is still the longest. **(20) [[Wake Forest University|Wake Forest]] 38, [[Maryland Terrapins|Maryland]] 24. The Demon Deacons now head [[Alltel Stadium|to Jacksonville]] and meet Georgia Tech for the ACC title. **(21) [[Brigham Young University|BYU]] 33, [[Utah Utes|Utah]] 31. The Cougars needed a Jonny Harline 11-yard touchdown catch from John Beck as time expire to beat their in-state rival for the first time in four years. **[[South Carolina Gamecocks football|South Carolina]] 31, (24) [[Clemson Tigers football|Clemson]] 28 **(25) [[Hawaii Warriors football|Hawai{{okina}}i]] 42, [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] 35 *[[Football (soccer)]]: **General news: ***[[Manchester United]] extends [[Wayne Rooney]]'s contract with another two seasons. Rooney is now committed to [[Old Trafford (football ground)|Old Trafford]] until 2012. **[[ELF Cup]], final: ***{{fb|Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus}} 3–1 {{fb-rt|Crimea}} *[[Rugby league]]: [[2006 Rugby League Tri-Nations]]: **{{flagicon|AUS}} [[Australia national rugby league team|Australia]] wins the series after defeating {{flagicon|NZL}} [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand]] 16–12 in golden point extra time in the final at [[Aussie Stadium]] in [[Sydney]]. *[[Rugby union]]: [[2007 Rugby World Cup qualifying]]: **{{ru|Japan}} qualify directly to the [[2007 Rugby World Cup|World Cup in France next year]], qualifying as Asia 1, after defeating Hong Kong and Korea in the final stages of the Asia tournaments. Japan join Pool B, along with [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]], [[Canada national rugby union team|Canada]], [[Fiji national rugby union team|Fiji]] and [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]. **{{ru|Georgia}} qualify as Europe 3, joining Pool D along with [[Argentina national rugby union team|Argentina]], hosts [[France national rugby union team|France]], [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] and [[Namibia national rugby union team|Namibia]]. *[[Rugby union]]: [[2006 Autumn internationals]]: **{{ru|RSA}} defeat {{ru|ENG}} 25–14 at [[Twickenham Stadium|Twickenham]], London **{{ru|AUS}} defeat {{ru|SCO}} 44–15 at [[Murrayfield Stadium|Murrayfield]] in [[Edinburgh]] **{{ru|NZL}} defeat {{ru|WAL}} 45–10 at [[Millennium Stadium]] in [[Cardiff]] **{{ru|FRA}} defeat {{ru|ARG}} 27–26 at [[Stade de France]] in [[Saint-Denis, Seine-Saint-Denis|Saint-Denis]] (Paris) **{{ru|ITA}} defeat {{ru|CAN}} 41–6 at [[Stadio Pordenone]] in [[Fontanafredda]] *[[Squash (sport)|Squash]], [[2006 Women's World Open Squash Championship]], semi finals: **[[Nicol David]] {{flagicon|MAS}} 9–7, 9–1, 9–1 {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Rachael Grinham]] **[[Natalie Grinham]] {{flagicon|AUS}} 9–4, 10–8, 9–6 {{flagicon|USA}} [[Natalie Grainger]]
==24 November 2006 (Friday)== *[[2006 Asian Games|Asian Games]]: **[[Basketball at the 2006 Asian Games|Basketball]] – {{flagicon|BHR}} Bahrain advances to the second round after winning Group A. **[[Football at the 2006 Asian Games|Football (soccer)]] – {{flagicon|JOR}} Jordan, {{flagicon|KGZ}} Kyrgyzstan, {{flagicon|IRQ|2004}} Iraq and {{flagicon|SYR}} Syria advance to the second round after finishing in the top two positions of their first round groups. *[[Auto racing]]: **[[Lewis Hamilton]] is announced to be the second driver for [[McLaren (racing)|McLaren]]'s [[Formula One]] team to race alongside world champion [[Fernando Alonso]]. He will be the first [[Black people|black]] driver in the Formula One history. *[[Cricket]]: **[[2006–07 Ashes series|The Ashes]] series between [[England cricket team|England]] and [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] continues at [[the Gabba]], [[Brisbane]]. [[Ricky Ponting]] scores 196 runs, four short of a [[Century (cricket)|double century]], and Australia declares at 9 for 602. In reply, England scores 3 for 53 by the close of play for the day. *[[Cycling]]: **[[Tinkoff Credit Systems]] signs two former [[doping (sport)|doping]] suspended cyclists to their team for the 2007 season. Olympic gold medallist [[Tyler Hamilton]] joins the team after three years of suspension, while [[Danilo Hondo]] returned in 2006 after being suspended for a year. *[[College football]]: [[Associated Press|AP]] NCAA Division I-A Top 25: **[[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M]] 12, (13) [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]] 7. Combined with the Longhorns' loss, [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] clinched a spot against Nebraska in Kansas City in the [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] Championship game next week with a win on Saturday (November 25) against [[Oklahoma State Cowboys|Oklahoma State]]. **(10) [[LSU Tigers football|LSU]] 31, (6) [[Arkansas Razorbacks|Arkansas]] 26. The Tigers knock the Razorbacks out of the national championship picture. **(22) [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]] 37, [[Colorado Buffaloes football|Colorado]] 14. **In another significant rivalry game: ***[[Oregon State Beavers|Oregon State]] 30, [[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]] 28. The Beavers win the 2006 edition of "[[Civil War (college football game)|The Civil War]]". *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[Sergei Sokolov (Azerbaijani footballer)|Sergei Sokolov]], member of the [[Azerbaijan national football team]] is suspended by [[UEFA]] after he was tested positive on using [[betamethason]]. The length of his suspension will be announced on 7 December 2006. Sokolov, defender at [[FK Karabakh]] claims to be innocent. However, he did not cooperate for a B-test. *[[Squash (sport)|Squash]], [[2006 Women's World Open Squash Championship]], quarter finals: **[[Nicol David]] {{flagicon|MAS}} 10–8, 9–2, 9–4 {{flagicon|EGY}} [[Omneya Abdel Kawy]] **[[Rachael Grinham]] {{flagicon|AUS}} 9–2, 9–3, 9–6 {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Laura Lengthorn]] **[[Natalie Grinham]] {{flagicon|AUS}} 9–5, 10–8, 9–5 {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Tania Bailey]] **[[Natalie Grainger]] {{flagicon|USA}} 9–2, 9–4, 9–5 {{flagicon|IRL}} [[Madeline Perry]]
==23 November 2006 (Thursday)== *[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: **[[2006–07 UEFA Cup]] Matchday 3. Teams that clinched advancement to the round of 32 today are in '''bold'''. ***Group A: [[AJ Auxerre]] 2 – 2 '''[[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]''' ***Group A: [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] 1 – 0 [[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]] ***Group B: [[Bayer Leverkusen]] 0 – 1 '''[[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]''' ***Group B: [[Club Brugge]] 1 – 1 [[FC Dinamo București|Dinamo Bucharest]] ***Group C: [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] 2 – 0 [[S.C Braga|Braga]] ***Group C: [[FC Slovan Liberec|Slovan Liberec]] 4 – 1 [[Grasshopper Club Zürich|Grasshoppers]] ***Group D: '''[[Parma F.C.|Parma]]''' 2 – 1 [[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]] ***Group D: [[Odense BK|Odense]] 1 – 1 [[RC Lens|Lens]] ***Group E: [[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]] 0 – 0 '''[[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]''' ***Group E: [[FC Basel]] 2 – 2 [[AS Nancy|Nancy]] ***Group F: [[AC Sparta Praha|Sparta Prague]] 0 – 0 [[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]] ***Group F: [[RCD Espanyol de Barcelona|Espanyol]] 6 – 2 [[S.V. Zulte-Waregem|Zulte-Waregem]] ***Group G: [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] 2 – 4 [[Hapoel Tel Aviv FC|Hapoel Tel Aviv]] ***Group G: [[FC Rapid Bucureşti|Rapid Bucharest]] 1 – 1 [[FK Mladá Boleslav|Mladá Boleslav]] ***Group H: [[Fenerbahçe SK|Fenerbahçe]] 3 – 0 [[Eintracht Frankfurt]] ***Group H: '''[[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]''' 2 – 1 [[Celta de Vigo|Celta Vigo]] **[[ELF Cup|ELF Cup Semi-finals]] ***{{fb|Kyrgyzstan}} 2–3 {{fb-rt|Crimea}} – Crimea goes on to the finals. ***{{fb|Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus}} 5–0 {{fb-rt|Zanzibar}} – TRNC goes on to the finals. **General news: ***The [[FIFA Emergency Committee]] decides to suspend the [[Islamic Republic of Iran Football Federation|IRIFF]] from all international competitions. This happens due to government interference in football matters. FIFA gave the IRIFF a deadline of 15 November 2006 to reinstate president [[Mohammed Dagdan]] who was elected, the IRIFF, however, did not follow this deadline. *[[Cricket]] **'''[[West Indian cricket team in Pakistan in 2006–07|West Indies v. Pakistan]], [[Test cricket|Second Test]] at [[Multan]]:''' The Second Test between [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] and [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] ends in a draw. Pakistan leads the three-Test series 1–0. [http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/pakvwi/engine/current/match/257766.html (Scorecard)] **[[2006–07 Ashes series|The Ashes]] series between [[England cricket team|England]] and [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] gets underway at [[the Gabba]], [[Brisbane]]. Australia win the toss and elect to bat, ending the first day of the First Test in a strong position on 346 [[Run (cricket)|runs]] for the loss of 3 [[wickets]]. *[[Football (American)|American football]]: **[[National Football League|NFL]] Week 12 [[Thanksgiving|Thanksgiving games]]: ***[[Miami Dolphins]] 27, [[Detroit Lions]] 10. [[Joey Harrington]]'s return to [[Ford Field]] was a measure of revenge on the team that released him, throwing for three touchdowns in the Dolphins' victory. ***[[Dallas Cowboys]] 38, [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] 10. [[Tony Romo]] tossed a club record five touchdowns as the Boys routed the Bucs. ***[[Kansas City Chiefs]] 19, [[Denver Broncos]] 10. Lawrence Tynes' four field goals provided the margin of victory. **[[College Football]]: *** [[Associated Press|AP]] NCAA Division I-A Top 25: [[Miami Hurricanes football|Miami (FL)]] 17, (18) [[Boston College]] 14. Even with [[Doug Flutie]] in attendance calling the game on [[ESPN]], the Eagles could not pull off another "Miracle in Miami" as the Canes become bowl eligible. However, it was not enough to save head coach [[Larry Coker]]'s job as he was fired the next day.
==22 November 2006 (Wednesday)== *[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]: **[[Noah Ngeny]], gold medallist at the [[2000 Summer Olympics]]' 1500 m after favourite [[Hicham El Guerrouj]] ends his international career at the age of 28. Ngeny still holds the world record of 2.11,96 at the 1000 m. *[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: **[[2006–07 UEFA Champions League]] Matchday 5 (Teams advancing in '''Bold'''): ***Group A: [[Werder Bremen]] 1 – 0 [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] ***Group A: [[PFC Levski Sofia|Levski Sofia]] 0 – 2 [[Barcelona F.C.|Barcelona]] ****Barca must win in their final match against Werner Bremen to make the top two and assure passage into the knockout stage. ***Group B: '''[[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Inter Milan]]''' 1 – 0 [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting]] ***Group B: [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] 2 – 2 '''[[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern München]]''' ****Bayern and Inter both advance to the knockout stage. ***Group C: [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] 3 – 1 [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray]] ***Group C: '''[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]''' 2 – 0 '''[[PSV Eindhoven]]''' ****Liverpool wins the group, and advances with Eindhoven. ***Group D: [[Shakhtar Donetsk]] 1 – 0 [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] ***Group D: '''[[Valencia CF|Valencia]]''' 2 – 0 [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiakos]] ****Roma advances with a win or a draw against Valencia, while Shakhtar loses to Olympiakos. **[[Lierse S.K.|Lierse SK]] appoints former player [[Kjetil Rekdal]] as their new manager to replace [[René Trost]]. Kjetil Rekdal resigned at [[Vålerenga I.F. Fotball|Vålerenga IF]] on 21 August 2006. **[[Henk Houwaart]] is the replacement of [[Thomas Caers]] at [[K. Sint-Truidense V.V.|Sint-Truiden]]. Dutchman Houwaart managed six other Belgian teams during his career. The last team he managed was [[AC Omonia]]. *[[Ice hockey]]: **The [[National Hockey League|NHL]] [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] name [[Ken Hitchcock]], who was fired as head coach of the [[Philadelphia Flyers]] earlier this season, as their new head coach, signing him to a three-year deal. His first game will be this Friday (11/24) against his former employers in [[Wachovia Center|Philadelphia]]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929122032/http://www.canada.com/topics/sports/story.html?id=aef4788f-0367-4ffe-b57b-2d3a5b3bab2f&k=39480 (Canada.com)] **[[Teemu Selänne|Teemu Selanne]] scored his 500th career NHL goal, however, the [[Anaheim Ducks]] lost to the [[Colorado Avalanche]] in a shootout, 3–2.
==21 November 2006 (Tuesday)== *[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: **[[ELF Cup|ELF Cup Group Stage]] ***Group A: {{fb|Greenland}} 0–1 {{fb-rt|Kyrgyzstan}} – Kyrgyzstan tops Group A and qualifies to the semi-finals. ***Group A: {{fb|Gagauzia}} 1–1 {{fb-rt|Zanzibar}} – Zanzibar gets 2nd place in Group A and qualifies to the semi-finals. ***Group B: {{fb|Tajikistan}} 1–2 {{fb-rt|Crimea}} – Crimea gets 2nd place in Group B and qualifies to the semi-finals. ***Group B: {{fb|Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus}} 10–0 {{fb|Tibet}} – Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus beat their former 'best win' record of 5–0 against [[Crimea national football team|Crimea]] with this score and qualifies to the semi-finals as top of Group B. **[[2006–07 UEFA Champions League]] Matchday 5 (Teams advancing in '''bold'''): ***Group E: [[FC Steaua București|Steaua Bucharest]] 1 – 1 [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]] ***Group E: '''[[Real Madrid]]''' 2 – 2 '''[[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]]''' ****Lyon and Real Madrid qualify for the last 16 from Group E. ***Group F: [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] 3 – 1 [[F.C. Copenhagen|København]] ***Group F: '''[[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]''' 1 – 0 [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] ****Celtic qualify for the last 16 for the first time through an 81st-minute goal by [[Shunsuke Nakamura]] and an 89th-minute penalty save by [[Artur Boruc]]. United need a point from their last game against Benfica. ***Group G: [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] 3 – 1 [[Hamburger SV|Hamburg]] ***Group G: [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] 0 – 2 [[F.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] ****Milan qualify for the last 16; AEK and Lille still depend on the results of their last matches. **The board of London's [[West Ham United F.C.]] accept an offer of £85 million from an [[Iceland]]ic consortium led by Iceland FA chairman [[Eggert Magnusson]] to buy the club. The consortium has also taken on the clubs' £22.5 million debt. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/6165272.stm (BBC)] *[[Major League Baseball]]: [[Justin Morneau]] of the [[Minnesota Twins]] is named the winner of the 2006 [[American League]] [[Major League Baseball Most Valuable Player Award|Most Valuable Player]]. *[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]]: Australian [[Ian Thorpe]], a five-time Olympic gold medalist, announces his retirement from the sport at the age of 24. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/swimming/5402568.stm (BBC)]
==20 November 2006 (Monday)== *[[Alpine skiing]]: [[Jose Maria Rienda Contreras]] suffers a heavy knee injury after falling during a training in preparation for the giant slalom World Cup in [[Aspen]]. Contreras, who won five World Cup meetings in her career will probably miss the whole alpine skiing season. *[[Major League Baseball]]: [[Philadelphia Phillies]] first baseman [[Ryan Howard]] followed winning the [[Major League Baseball Rookie of the Year Award|Rookie of the Year]] award in 2005 with the 2006 [[Major League Baseball Most Valuable Player Award|Most Valuable Player]] award in the [[National League]], becoming the fourth sophomore to do so. *[[Cycling]]: Former [[Denmark|Danish]] cyclist [[Jesper Skibby]] confirms to have used [[doping (sport)|doping]] during his career for years. Skibby writes this confession in his book that is released on 21 November. *[[National Football League|NFL]] [[Monday Night Football]]: [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] 26, [[New York Giants]] 10. The Giants were held to a total of 26 yards rushing and are now tied with the Cowboys for first place in the NFC East. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[ELF Cup|ELF Cup Group Stage]] ***Group A: {{fb|Gagauzia}} 2 – 6 {{fb-rt|Kyrgyzstan}} ***Group A: {{fb|Greenland}} 1 – 1 {{fb-rt|Zanzibar}} ***Group B: {{fb|Tibet}} 0 – 1 {{fb-rt|Crimea}} ***Group B: {{fb|Tajikistan}} 1 – 5 {{fb-rt|Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus}} – Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus guarantees qualification into semi-finals. **[[2007 ASEAN Football Championship]] Qualifying Round: ***{{fb|LAO}} and {{fb|PHI}} advance to the finals of the tournament which will be held in 2007. ***With the top teams advancing to the finals, Laos overcame [[Brunei national football team|Brunei]] 4–1 to clinch first place at the sole group ***The Philippines, which only needed a draw to qualify, beat the same Brunei team, 4–1, to clinch second place. ***They will be joined by {{fb|IDN}}, {{fb|MAS}}, {{fb|MYA|1974}}, {{fb|SIN}}, {{fb|THA}} and {{fb|VIE}}. **General news: ***[[São Paulo Futebol Clube|São Paulo FC]] wins the [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A]] for the fourth time in the history of the club, with still two more games to play. São Paulo's 1–1 draw versus [[Clube Atlético Paranaense|Atlético Paranaense]] was enough to claim the title as the only opponent that was left [[Sport Club Internacional|Internacional]] lost 1–0 versus [[Paraná Clube|Paraná]]. ***[[Frans Adelaar]] resigns as manager of [[ADO Den Haag]] one day after the match versus [[Vitesse Arnhem]] was abandoned at 0–3 when unhappy fans entered the pitch. Some fans were threatening Adelaar, who took his conclusions. Assistant manager [[Lex Schoenmaker]] will take care of the first team. Shirt sponsor "DSW" decided to remove the name of their company from the shirts immediately.
==19 November 2006 (Sunday)== *[[Red Bull Air Race World Series|Air Race World Series]]: [[Kirby Chambliss]] is crowned World Champion in [[Perth, Western Australia]]. *[[Auto racing]]: **[[2006 Chase for the NEXTEL Cup|Chase for the 2006 NEXTEL Cup]]: [[Ford 400]] in [[Homestead-Miami Speedway|Homestead, Florida]] ***(1) [[Greg Biffle]] (2) [[Martin Truex, Jr.]] (3) [[Denny Hamlin]]; (6) [[Matt Kenseth]]; (9) [[Jimmie Johnson]]. Greg Biffle wins his third in a row in Miami, but Jimmie Johnson finishes ninth to clinch the 2006 NEXTEL Cup championship despite Matt Kenseth's sixth-place finish. *[[Baseball]]: **[[Major League Baseball]]: The [[Chicago Cubs]] reportedly sign [[Alfonso Soriano]] to an eight-year, $134 million ([[United States dollar|US]]) contract according to [[Associated Press|AP]]. **In the [[2006 Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] championship, [[Cuba national baseball team|Cuba]] defeated [[Netherlands national baseball team|Netherlands]] 6–3, while [[Chinese Taipei national baseball team|Chinese Taipei]]([[Taiwan]]), the host country, won the third place game, shutting out [[Japan national baseball team|Japan]] 4–0. *[[National Football League|NFL]] Week 11 Games: **[[Baltimore Ravens]] 24, [[Atlanta Falcons]] 10. [[Jamal Lewis]] scored three touchdowns in the Ravens' win. **[[Buffalo Bills]] 24, [[Houston Texans]] 21. [[Peerless Price]]'s 15-yard touchdown catch from [[J. P. Losman]] with nine seconds left gave the Bills the come-from-behind victory. Losman threw two first quarter 83-yard touchdown passes to [[Lee Evans (American football)|Lee Evans]] as part of Evans' club record 265 receiving yards on the day, while [[David Carr (American football)|David Carr]] tied the NFL mark of 22 straight passes completed in the loss. **[[Chicago Bears]] 10 [[New York Jets]] 0. The Monsters of the Midway return to [[Giants Stadium|The Meadowlands]] a week after beating the [[New York Giants|Giants]] and shut out the Jets. **[[Cincinnati Bengals]] 31, [[New Orleans Saints]] 16. In spite of [[Drew Brees]] throwing for 510 yards, [[Carson Palmer]] and [[Chad Ochocinco|Chad Johnson]] (a/k/a "Ocho Cinco") connect for three touchdowns in the Bengals' win. **[[Miami Dolphins]] 24, [[Minnesota Vikings]] 20. [[Jason Taylor (American football)|Jason Taylor]] provided one of two Dolphin returns for touchdowns in this win. **[[New England Patriots]] 35, [[Green Bay Packers]] 0. [[Brett Favre]] injured his right elbow in this game, and his status (272 straight starts) is in jeopardy for next week's game. Favre's backup, [[Aaron Rogers]], was lost for the season with a foot injury. Fellow [[Super Bowl]] winning quarterback [[Tom Brady]], tossed four touchdowns in the rout. **[[Kansas City Chiefs]] 17, [[Oakland Raiders]] 13. [[Trent Green]] fared better in his return as the Chiefs' starting quarterback than his Raiders' counterpart, [[Aaron Brooks (American football)|Aaron Brooks]], as [[Larry Johnson (running back)|Larry Johnson]]'s one-yard touchdown was the difference. **[[Pittsburgh Steelers]] 24, [[Cleveland Browns]] 20. [[Ben Roethlisberger]]'s four-yard shovel pass to [[Willie Parker]] with 32 seconds left was the difference. **[[Carolina Panthers]] 15, [[St. Louis Rams]] 0. The Rams were shut out for the first time since the 1998 season by the Panthers. **[[Tennessee Titans]] 31, [[Philadelphia Eagles]] 13. [[Donovan McNabb]] is lost for the season with a torn [[anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]] in his right knee. The Titans' upset was led by [[Travis Henry]]'s 125 yards rushing and [[Pacman Jones|Adam "Pacman" Jones]]' 90-yard punt return for a game-breaking touchdown. **[[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] 20, [[Washington Redskins]] 17. Even with a new starting quarterback in [[Jason Campbell]], the Redskins sputtered to another loss, this time [[Raymond James Stadium|in Tampa]]. **[[Arizona Cardinals]] 17, [[Detroit Lions]] 10. The Cards win their second game of the year, their first with [[Matt Leinart]] as their starting quarterback. **[[San Francisco 49ers]] 20, [[Seattle Seahawks]] 17. On the day [[Jerry Rice]] was honored with the retirement of his number 80 jersey, [[Frank Gore]] resets the franchise's all-time single game rushing mark (212 yards) for the second straight week, upstaging a returning [[Shaun Alexander]]. **[[Dallas Cowboys]] 21, [[Indianapolis Colts]] 14. Thanks to four turnovers in the first six Colts second half possessions, the Cowboys end their unbeaten run, meaning the 1972 Miami Dolphins can uncork the champagne as they remain the only team in NFL history to finish a season (including the post-season) undefeated. **[[San Diego Chargers]] 35, [[Denver Broncos]] 27. For the second straight week, [[LaDainian Tomlinson]] scores four touchdowns, including his 100th career touchdown in his 89th game, and the Chargers take control of the AFC West with this "Flex Game" win. *[[Canadian Football League]]: **[[94th Grey Cup]] Final at [[Canad Inns Stadium|Winnipeg, Manitoba]]: [[B.C. Lions]] 25, [[Montreal Alouettes|Montréal Alouettes]] 14. The Lions win their fifth CFL championship, thanks in part to Paul McCallum's Grey Cup record six field goals. Robert Edwards' fumble on the Lions' goal line kills Montreal's comeback attempt. *[[Football (soccer)]] **[[ELF Cup|ELF Cup Group Stage]] ***Group A: {{fb|Gagauzia}} 0 – 2 {{fb-rt|Greenland}} ***Group A: {{fb|Kyrgyzstan}} 0 – 1 {{fb-rt|Zanzibar}} ***Group B: {{fb|Tibet}} 0 – 3 {{fb-rt|Tajikistan}} ***Group B: {{fb|Crimea}} 0 – 5 {{fb-rt|Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus}} – Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus beat their former 'best win' record of 6–2 against [[Sápmi national football team|Sápmi]] with this score. *[[Golf]]: [[2007 European Tour]]: [[Hong Kong Open (golf)|USB Hong Kong Open]]: *** [[José Manuel Lara]] wins his first [[PGA European Tour|European Tour]] event by finishing 15 under par and just 1 stroke in front of [[Juvic Pagunsan]]. The third spot is shared by [[Jeev Milkha Singh]], [[Thongchai Jaidee]] and [[Jyoti Randhawa]]. *[[Ice hockey]]: The [[New York Rangers]]' [[Jaromír Jágr|Jaromir Jagr]] scores his 600th [[National Hockey League|NHL]] goal 1:43 into the game as the Rangers beat the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]], 4–1. Jagr joins teammate [[Brendan Shanahan]] as a member of the 600 goal club this season. *[[Team handball|Handball (beach)]]: [[2006 Beach Handball World Championships]]: **men's medal matches: ***Gold ==18 November 2006 (Saturday)== *[[Baseball]] **[[2006 Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] – [[Taichung]], [[Taiwan]], semi finals. ***{{flagicon|Japan}} [[Japan national baseball team|Japan]] 0–3 {{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Netherlands national baseball team|The Netherlands]] ***{{flagicon|Cuba}} [[Cuba national baseball team|Cuba]] 5–4 {{flagicon|Chinese Taipei}} [[Chinese Taipei baseball team|Chinese Taipei]]([[Taiwan]]) – The Taiwanese came short in their eighth inning comeback bid, failing to repeat the upset of two nights earlier. * [[Boxing]]: Fights at the [[Thomas and Mack Center]], [[Las Vegas, Nevada]] ([http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2667821 ESPN]): **Undercard: {{flagicon|Mexico}} [[Omar Niño Romero]] fought {{flagicon|USA}} [[Brian Viloria]] to a majority draw; Romero retains the WBC light-flyweight (108 lbs.) championship. **Undercard: {{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Ricardo Torres (boxer)|Ricardo Torres]] defeated {{flagicon|Greece}} [[Mike Arnaoutis]] via a split decision to win the vacant WBO junior welterweight (140 lbs.) championship. **Main event: {{flagicon|Philippines}} [[Manny Pacquiao]] knocked out {{flagicon|Mexico}} [[Erik Morales]] in the third round to retain the WBC International super featherweight (130 lbs.) championship. **The card drew 18,276 people, the second largest crowd at the arena in its history. * [[Track cycling|Cycling (track)]]: [[Anna Meares]] sets a new World Record at the 500 m individual time trial at the [[2007 UCI Track Cycling World Cup Classics]] meeting in [[Sydney]]. The new world best time is 33.944 seconds. * [[Canadian football|Football (Canadian)]]: [[Canadian Interuniversity Sport]] semifinals: ** [[Uteck Bowl]]: (2) [[Laval Rouge et Or]] 57, (10) [[Acadia Axemen]] 10 – Laval is the beneficiary of five Axemen turnovers in the first half alone, and will make their third [[Vanier Cup]] appearance since 2003. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929120818/http://www.tsn.ca/cis/news_story/?ID=184877&hubname= (TSN)] ** [[Mitchell Bowl]]: (4) [[Saskatchewan Huskies]] 35, (3) [[Ottawa Gee-Gees]] 28 – Saskatchewan advances to the Vanier Cup, which will be held in their home stadium, the first for any school outside of the [[Ontario University Athletics|OUA]]. [[Tyler O'Gorman]] rushed for three touchdowns (two in the fourth quarter) in the Huskies victory. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929162536/http://www.tsn.ca/cis/news_story/?ID=184938&hubname= (TSN)] *[[College football|Football (U.S. college)]]: **[[Associated Press|AP]] NCAA Division I-A Top 25: ***(1) [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]] 42, (2) [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] 39. The Buckeyes are the [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] champions, and clinch the Number One [[Bowl Championship Series|BCS]] ranking, earning a bid to the BCS Title Game, while the Wolverines could be (as the game was close) at best their opposition in [[University of Phoenix Stadium|Glendale, Arizona]] on January 8 or in the [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] on New Year's Day facing [[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-10]] champion [[USC Trojans football|Southern California]]. ***(3) [[Florida Gators football|Florida]] 62, [[Western Carolina University|Western Carolina]] 0 ***(4) [[USC Trojans football|Southern California]] 23, (17) [[California Golden Bears|California]] 9. Southern California wins no worse than a Rose Bowl bid and the Pac-10 championship for the fifth straight time outright or shared. ***(5) [[Arkansas Razorbacks|Arkansas]] 28, [[Mississippi State University|Mississippi State]] 14. The Razorbacks lock up a spot as the West Division champion and earn a trip to the [[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] Championship against Florida. ***(6) [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] 41, [[Army Black Knights football|Army]] 9. The Irish don their green jerseys for Senior Day, and (in essence) win the [[Commander-in-Chief's Trophy]] defeating all three service academies (Army, [[Air Force Falcons football|Air Force]] and [[Navy Midshipmen football|Navy]]). ***[[Cincinnati Bearcats|Cincinnati]] 30, (7) [[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] 11. The Bearcats knock Rutgers from the unbeaten ranks, and now create chaos at the top of the [[Big East Conference (1979–2013)|Big East]] between Rutgers, Louisville and [[West Virginia Mountaineers|West Virginia]]. ***(9) [[LSU Tigers football|LSU]] 23, [[University of Mississippi|Ole Miss]] 20 (OT). The Bayou Bengals escape the upset bid of the Rebels, and end 8–0 for the first time [[Tiger Stadium (LSU)|at home]]. ***(10) [[Louisville Cardinals|Louisville]] 31, [[South Florida Bulls football|South Florida]] 8 ***(12) [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]] 35, [[Buffalo Bulls football|Buffalo]] 3. The Badgers set a school record with their eleventh regular-season win. ***(13) [[Boise State Broncos football|Boise State]] 49, [[Utah State University|Utah State]] 10. The Broncos clinch the [[Western Athletic Conference|WAC]] crown. Next up, a trip to [[University of Nevada, Reno|Nevada]] for an unbeaten regular season and a chance at a BCS bowl berth. ***(19) [[Virginia Tech Hokies football|Virginia Tech]] 27, (14) [[Wake Forest University|Wake Forest]] 6 ***(15) [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]] 22, [[University of Alabama athletics|Alabama]] 15. Auburn wins its fifth straight [[Iron Bowl]], its longest winning streak in the series since 1958. The Tigers also have yet to lose an Iron Bowl game [[Bryant–Denny Stadium|in Tuscaloosa]]. ***(16) [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] 36, [[Baylor Bears|Baylor]] 10 ***(18) [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets|Georgia Tech]] 49, [[Duke Blue Devils|Duke]] 21. The Yellow Jackets have reserved a date in the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]] Championship December 2 [[Alltel Stadium|in Jacksonville]] with this win. ***(20) [[Boston College Eagles|Boston College]] 38, (21) [[University of Maryland athletics|Maryland]] 16 ***(22) [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]] 39, [[Vanderbilt University|Vanderbilt]] 10 ***(23) [[Brigham Young University|BYU]] 42, [[University of New Mexico|New Mexico]] 17. The Cougars clinch the [[Mountain West Conference|Mountain West]] title. **Other significant games: ***[[University of Houston|Houston]] 23, [[Memphis Tigers|Memphis]] 20 (OT). The Cougars, already assured of a spot in the [[Conference USA]] title game, secure the best overall conference record, meaning that the game will be held at [[Robertson Stadium|their home field]] on December 1. ***[[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] 17, [[Michigan State Spartans football|Michigan State]] 13. Penn State's [[Joe Paterno]], recovering from a broken leg suffered two weeks ago in the Wisconsin game, returns to coaching, staying in the press box on medical advice. ***[[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] 28, [[Indiana Hoosiers football|Indiana]] 19. The Boilermakers beat the Hoosiers in the annual rivalry game for The [[Old Oaken Bucket]]. Purdue improves to an overall record of 8–4, while Indiana sees its season come to an end after failing to secure a spot in a bowl. Indiana hasn't been in a bowl game since 1991, and finishes its season at 5–7 under the helm of second year Head Coach [[Terry Hoeppner]]. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] retains their [[Russian Premier League]] title after winning 0–4 at [[FC Luch-Energia Vladivostok]]. [[FC Spartak Moscow]] is able to equal CSKA in points, but if that happens CSKA would still win due to having won more league matches during the season. *[[Team handball|Handball (beach)]]: [[2006 ==17 November 2006 (Friday)== *[[Major League Baseball]]: [[Bob Geren]] has been promoted to manager of the [[Oakland Athletics]] after a month-long search to replace [[Ken Macha]]. *[[Cycling]]: **When signing his new contract with [[Discovery Channel Pro Cycling Team|Team Discovery Channel]], [[Ivan Basso]] said he is willing to undergo a [[DNA test]] to clarify he is innocent in the [[doping (sport)|doping]] scandal of the [[2006 Tour de France]]. It is unknown whether this will happen or not. *[[Domino Day]]: ** For the eighth time in nine years the world record for the highest number of falling [[domino]] stones is broken during [[Domino Day]]. In [[Leeuwarden]] 4,079,381 out of 4,500,000 domino stones fell, breaking the world record by 77,245 stones. *[[College Football]]: On the eve of the #1 [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]] vs. #2 [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] game, former Wolverines head coach [[Bo Schembechler]] died at the age of 77 after collapsing outside the studios of [[WXYZ-TV]] near [[Detroit]]. *[[Jujutsu]]: 2006 Jujutsu World Championships: **men's −62 kg: {{goca}} {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Anders Lauridsen]], {{sica}} {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Francisco García (ju-jitsu)|Francisco García]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|FRA}} Nicolas Gimenez, {{Brca}} {{flagicon|AUT}} [[Oliver Haider]] **men's −85 kg: {{goca}} {{flagicon|GER}} [[Andreas Kuhl]], {{sica}} {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Dmitry Nebolsin]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Jakob Tideman]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Franck Vatan]] **men's duo systems: {{goca}} {{flagicon|SUI}} [[Pascal Müller|P. Müller]] / [[Remo Müller|R. Müller]], {{sica}} {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Karim Ben Boudaoud|Ben Boudaoud]] / [[Gregoire Cordesse|Cordesse]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|NED}} [[Barry van Bommel|Van Bommel]] / [[Ron Soechit|Soechit]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|GER}} [[Florens Goldbeck|Goldbeck]] / [[Felix Schmidt|Schmidt]] **women's −55 kg: {{goca}} {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Annabelle Reydy]], {{sica}} {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Linda Lindström]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|GER}} [[Andrea Pflefka]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|POL}} [[Monika Dikow-Iwanow]] **women's −70 kg: {{goca}} {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Taja Luthje]], {{sica}} {{flagicon|NED}} [[Albertine Los]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Melanie Lavis]], {{Brca}} {{flagicon|GER}} [[Seher Dumanli]] *[[Tennis]]: [[2006 Tennis Masters Cup]], [[Shanghai]]: **Singles, Gold group: [[Rafael Nadal]] beats [[Nikolay Davydenko]] 5–7, 6–4, 6–4 to claim his spot in the semi finals alongside [[James Blake (tennis)|James Blake]] who lost his last match versus [[Tommy Robredo]] 6–2, 3–6, 7–5, but still became group winner. Second seed Nadal will now meet first seed [[Roger Federer]] in the semi finals. **Doubles, Gold group: [[Jonas Björkman]] and [[Max Mirnyi]] qualify for the semi finals as the group winners. They will be joined by [[Mark Knowles]] and [[Daniel Nestor]] who won their last match versus [[Mariusz Fyrstenberg]] and [[Marcin Matkowski]]. [[Fabrice Santoro]] and [[Nenad Zimonjić]] are eliminated as well. *Other sports: **[[Speed skating]]: [[2007 Speed Skating World Cup]] meeting in Berlin **[[Track cycling]]: [[2007 UCI Track Cycling World Cup Classics]] meeting in [[Sydney]]
==16 November 2006 (Thursday)== *[[Baseball]] **[[2006 Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] – [[Taichung]], [[Taiwan]]. All times [[GMT+9]] ***[[Italy national baseball team|Italy]] {{flagicon|Italy}} 1–5 [[Korea national baseball team|South Korea]]{{flagicon|South Korea}} Italy eliminated from medal contention. ***[[Japan national baseball team|Japan]] {{flagicon|Japan}} 17–0 [[Philippines national baseball team|The Philippines]] {{flagicon|Philippines}} (6½ innings – [[mercy rule]]) ***[[Netherlands national baseball team|The Netherlands]] {{flagicon|Netherlands}} 4–3 [[Australia national baseball team|Australia]] {{flagicon|Australia}} (11 innings) – Dutch gain the third qualifying spot. Australia eliminated from medal round. ***[[Chinese Taipei baseball team|Chinese Taipei]]([[Taiwan]]) {{flagicon|Chinese Taipei}} 4–3 [[Cuba national baseball team|Cuba]] {{flagicon|Cuba}} Taiwan stuns Cuba to advance to the medal round, inspired by [[Chien-Ming Wang]], who made an appearance before the game. **[[Major League Baseball]] For the second time in three years, [[Johan Santana]] of the [[Minnesota Twins]] wins the [[American League]] [[Cy Young Award]] with a unanimous vote. *[[College football|Football (U.S. college)]]: **[[Associated Press|AP]] NCAA Division I-A Top 25 ***(8) [[West Virginia Mountaineers|West Virginia]] 45, [[University of Pittsburgh Panthers|Pittsburgh]] 27. The Mountaineers win the [[Backyard Brawl]], with quarterback [[Patrick White (American football)|Patrick White]] and running back [[Steve Slaton]] each rushing for over 200 yards and two touchdowns. White adds two TD passes, and Slaton also becomes the first WVU player ever to gain 100 yards rushing and 100 yards receiving in the same game. **Other significant games: ***[[Ohio Bobcats football|Ohio]] 17, [[University of Akron|Akron]] 7. The Bobcats win the [[Mid-American Conference|MAC]] East Division, and will play [[Central Michigan Chippewas football|Central Michigan]] on November 30 [[Ford Field|in Detroit]] for the MAC crown. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[Bora Milutinović]] who coached five different nations to a [[FIFA World Cup]] tournament is appointed as the new coach of [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]]. In [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] former [[Real Madrid]] player [[Hugo Sánchez]] is appointed as their national coach to replace [[Ricardo La Volpe]] whose contract was not renewed after the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]. **The [[Belgian Football Association|KBVB]] is doing research to whether [[Jacek Bąk]]'s story about a possible attempt to bribe him before the [[Euro 2008]] qualifier between [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] and [[Poland national football team|Poland]] is true or not. The Polish international said he would have been awarded €10,000 if he caused a penalty in Belgian favour. *[[Rugby union]]: **The [[South African Rugby Union]], its commercial arm of SA Rugby, and the [[Southern Spears]] reach a settlement of the court case that threatened to throw a monkey wrench into the [[2007 Super 14 season]]. The financially troubled Spears drop their lawsuit against the SARU and SA Rugby, and abandon their quest to enter the [[Super Rugby|Super 14]]. This means that the [[Lions (rugby franchise)|Lions]], formerly the Cats, are spared from relegation and will play in the 2007 Super 14. [http://www.planet-rugby.com/Teams/South_Africa/story_55239.shtml (Planet-Rugby.com)]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[[Tennis]]: [[2006 Tennis Masters Cup]], [[Shanghai]]: **Singles, Red group: [[Roger Federer]] beats [[Ivan Ljubičić]] 7–6, 6–4 and wins all three of his group matches. [[David Nalbandian]] joins Federer in the semi finals after he beat [[Andy Roddick]] 6–2, 7–6 in the decisive match. **Doubles, Red group: [[Paul Hanley (tennis)|Paul Hanley]] and [[Kevin Ullyett]] qualify for the semi finals as the group winners. They will be joined by [[Martin Damm]] and [[Leander Paes]] who won the confrontation with [[Jonathan Erlich]] and [[Andy Ram]]. The brothers and first seeds [[Bob Bryan|Bob]] and [[Mike Bryan]] are eliminated as well. *[[Volleyball]]: [[2006 FIVB Women's World Championship]] finals: **Gold medal match: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Russia women's national volleyball team|Russia]] 3–2 [[Brazil women's national volleyball team|Brazil]] {{flagicon|BRA}} **Bronze medal match: {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Italy women's national volleyball team|Italy]] 0–3 [[Serbia women's national volleyball team|Serbia]] {{flagicon|SER}}
==15 November 2006 (Wednesday)== *[[Auto racing]]: [[Formula One]]: **[[Anthony Davidson]] will be the second driver of the [[Super Aguri F1]] team during the [[2007 Formula One season]]. [[Takuma Sato]] remains the first driver of the team. *[[Baseball]] **[[2006 Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]], [[Taichung]], [[Taiwan]] – Sixth day of [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] play. Game times Taichung time ([[UTC+8]]) ***[[Italy national baseball team|Italy]] {{flagicon|Italy}} 3–6 [[Japan national baseball team|Japan]] {{flagicon|Japan}} – Japan clinches at least second seed, Italy's hopes are very faint ***[[Korea national baseball team|South Korea]] {{flagicon|South Korea}} 2–13 [[Netherlands national baseball team|The Netherlands]] {{flagicon|Netherlands}} (8 innings [[mercy rule]]) – South Korea is eliminated. The Dutch are in the driver's seat for third, but have yet to clinch medal round berth.. ***[[Cuba national baseball team|Cuba]] {{flagicon|Cuba}} 13–0 [[Australia national baseball team|Australia]] {{flagicon|Australia}} (5 innings – rain) – Cuba clinches top seed; Australia falls to fifth ***[[Philippines national baseball team|The Philippines]] {{flagicon|Philippines}} 0–14 [[Chinese Taipei baseball team|Chinese Taipei]]([[Taiwan]]) {{flagicon|Chinese Taipei}} (6 innings – rain) – Chinese Taipei ([[Taiwan]]) moves into fourth with one day to go in [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] **[[Major League Baseball]] ***Despite being fired by the [[Florida Marlins]], [[Joe Girardi]] was named winner of the 2006 [[National League]] [[Major League Baseball Manager of the Year Award|Manager of the Year]]. Girardi will serve as an [[color commentator|analyst]] with the [[YES Network]] for [[New York Yankees]] telecasts in 2007. Meanwhile, [[Detroit Tigers]] skipper [[Jim Leyland]] wins the honors in the [[American League]], his third overall as previous awards were won with the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] in 1990 and again in 1992. ***The [[Seibu Lions]] will receive a $51.1 million ([[United States dollar|US]]) fee from the [[Boston Red Sox]] for a 30-day negotiation period with Lions pitcher [[Daisuke Matsuzaka]] as announced in a newsconference held at 10 AM in Tokyo. The fee would only be refundable if the Red Sox fail to sign him before the end of the period. The previous high fee for negotiations was the $13.25 million (US) the [[Seattle Mariners]] paid for a 30-day period with [[Ichiro Suzuki|Ichiro]] in [[2000 in baseball|2000]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=2662193 ESPN.com story] *[[Basketball]]: **[[Egypt]]ian basketball team [[Gezira Sports Club]] withdraws their entry into the [[2006 Haarlem Basketball Week]] due to the appearance of the [[Israel national basketball team]]. The Egyptian government forbids their team to play in the same tournament, even when drawn in separate groups as there would be an opportunity to face each other in the final. *[[Cycling]]: **The French anti-doping lab of [[Chatenay-Malabry]] that tested [[Floyd Landis]]' urine samples made an administrative error when reporting its findings on his backup B-sample. In its report, the lab wrote that the B-sample tested was number 994,474, while the actual number was 995,474. The error does not mean the positive B-sample was not that of Landis, but it will be used by his lawyers. *[[Field hockey]]: **[[Sylvia Karres]], [[Chantal de Bruijn]] and [[Eveline de Haan]] will no longer play in international matches for the [[Netherlands women's national field hockey team]]. The three leave the team that became World Champion this year due to personal reasons. Karres was top goalscorer of the tournament when the Netherlands became World Champion. *[[Football (soccer)]] **[[2007 AFC Asian Cup qualification]] – 11 matches, but only three affect qualification as ten of twelve qualifying spots are taken. ***Group D: {{fb|BHR}} 2 – 1 {{fb-rt|KUW}} – Bahrain got the win they needed to qualify from the group. ***Group F: {{fb|UZB}} 2 – 0 {{fb-rt|QAT}} – The win was more than Uzbekistan required, they needed to avoid a 10-goal defeat against the group leaders. *** The Singapore–Palestine clash is called off due to travel difficulties for the visitors. *** {{fb|JPN}} (Group A) and {{fb|IRN}} (Group B) win top-of-the-table clashes to take top spots in their groups ahead of {{fb|KSA}} and {{fb|KOR}}. **[[Euro 2008 qualifying|2008 UEFA European Football Championship qualifying]] ***Group A: {{fb|FIN}} 1 – 0 {{fb-rt|ARM}} ***Group A: {{fb|BEL}} 0 – 1 {{fb-rt|POL}} ***Group A: {{fb|POR}} 3 – 0 {{fb-rt|KAZ}} ***Group D: {{fb|IRL}} 5 – 0 {{fb-rt|SMR}} – Ireland give their old [[Lansdowne Road]] stadium a fine send off in the last match before it is rebuilt. ***Group D: {{fb|CYP}} 1 – 1 {{fb-rt|GER}} – Germany lose their 100% record. ***Group E: {{fb|MKD}} 0 – 2 {{fb-rt|RUS}} ***Group E: {{fb|ISR}} 3 – 4 {{fb-rt|CRO}} – Israel's first home defeat in three and a half years. **General news: ***During the rest of the season in the [[Argentine Primera División]], no more visiting fans are allowed into the stadiums due to heavy violence in the last couple of weeks. On November 12 the match between [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] and [[Racing Club de Avellaneda|Racing Club]] was suspended when Racing fans attacked police forces inside the stadium. It was the third match this season that was suspended due to supporter's violence. ***[[Clarence Seedorf]] made his comeback in [[Netherlands national football team|Oranje]] during the friendly match versus [[England national football team|England]]. Seedorf who had his last cap at 30 June 2004 played the whole 90 minutes. It was the first time he played a match under the current manager [[Marco van Basten]]. *[[Snooker]]: [[2006 IBSF World Championships]]: **men's final: ***{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Kurt Maflin]] def. {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Daniel Ward (snooker player)|Daniel Ward]] 11–8 *[[Tennis]]: [[2006 Tennis Masters Cup]], [[Shanghai]]: **Golden group: [[James Blake (tennis)|James Blake]] advances to the semi finals by beating [[Nikolay Davydenko]] 2–6, 6–4, 7–5. [[Rafael Nadal]] wins 7–6, 6–2 versus [[Tommy Robredo]]. Nadal and Davydenko face each other for a place in the semi finals. *[[Volleyball]]: [[2006 FIVB Women's World Championship]] semi finals: **{{flagicon|ITA}} [[Italy women's national volleyball team|Italy]] 0–3 [[Russia women's national volleyball team|Russia]] {{flagicon|RUS}} **{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Brazil women's national volleyball team|Brazil]] 3–1 [[Serbia women's national volleyball team|Serbia]] {{flagicon|SER}}
==14 November 2006 (Tuesday)== *[[Baseball]] **[[2006 Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] ([[Taichung]], [[Taiwan]]) – Day five of [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] games. ***[[Cuba national baseball team|Cuba]] {{flagicon|Cuba}} 6–3 [[Japan national baseball team|Japan]] {{flagicon|Japan}} Cuba wins the battle of undefeated teams and is the first to clinch a medal round berth. ***[[Italy national baseball team|Italy]] {{flagicon|Italy}} 9–0 [[Philippines national baseball team|The Philippines]] {{flagicon|Philippines}} Italy stays in the medal hunt, improves to 2–3. ***[[Australia national baseball team|Australia]] {{flagicon|Australia}} 10–9 [[Korea national baseball team|South Korea]] {{flagicon|South Korea}} – Australia gets a big win to move into fourth, virtually eliminating South Korea in the process. ***[[Chinese Taipei baseball team|Chinese Taipei]]([[Taiwan]]) {{flagicon|Chinese Taipei}} 2–4 [[Netherlands national baseball team|The Netherlands]] {{flagicon|Netherlands}} (10 innings) – Dutch stay in third with the victory, dropping the Taiwanese to sixth, but not without hope. **[[Major League Baseball]]: ***[[Brandon Webb]] of the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] wins the [[National League]] [[Cy Young Award]]. ***[[Manny Acta]], who was the third base coach under [[Frank Robinson]] with the late Montréal Expos, returns to the franchise replacing Robinson as manager of the [[Washington Nationals]]. *[[Cricket]] **'''[[West Indian cricket team in Pakistan in 2006–07|West Indies in Pakistan]], [[Test cricket|First Test]] at [[Gaddafi Stadium]], [[Lahore]]:''' {{cr|PAK}} defeats {{cr|West Indies}} by nine wickets. West Indies, having won the toss and electing to bat, were dismissed for 206 in their first innings, [[Umar Gul]] taking 5/65. Pakistan's response was centred around [[Mohammad Yousuf (cricketer, born 1974)|Mohammad Yousuf]]'s innings of 192; with support from [[Kamran Akmal]], [[Shoaib Malik]] and [[Mohammad Hafeez]], Pakistan compiled a healthy 485. Despite a century (122) from captain [[Brian Lara]], Umar Gul claimed another four wickets to restrict the visitors to 291, a lead of only 13. Pakistan achieved the total with the loss of only one wicket, that of Hafeez in the third over. [http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/pakvwi/engine/current/match/257765.html (Scorecard)] *[[American football|Football (American)]]: The [[New England Patriots]] will install [[FieldTurf]], an artificial surface, into [[Gillette Stadium]] to replace a poorly maintained grass surface effective for their November 26 game against the [[Chicago Bears]]. Normally, the change could not take place until the following season, but there was no such rule in the [[National Football League|NFL]], according to Patriots owner [[Robert Kraft]]. A game two days earlier where they lost to the [[New York Jets]] in a steady downpour when a new grass surface installed one week earlier gradually became worse throughout the game, was the main cause of the decision. *[[Football (soccer)]]: General news: ** [[Josep Guardiola]] ends his career at the age of 35. Guardiola won [[La Liga]] 6 times, the [[Copa del Rey]] 2 times as well as the [[UEFA Champions League]], the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] and the gold medal at the [[1992 Summer Olympics]]. ** [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] appoints [[Les Reed (football coach)|Les Reed]] as their new manager to replace [[Iain Dowie]]. Reed was Dowie's assistant before he left the club. *[[Snooker]]: [[2006 IBSF World Championships]]: **men's quarter finals: ***{{flagicon|IND}} [[Manan Chandra]] def. {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Craig Steadman]] 6–3 ***{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Daniel Ward (snooker player)|Daniel Ward]] def. {{flagicon|HKG}} [[Fung Kwok Wai]] 6–3 ***{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Kurt Maflin]] def. {{flagicon|WAL}} [[Philip Williams (snooker player)|Philip Williams]] 6–3 ***{{flagicon|THA}} [[Atthasit Mahitthi]] def. {{flagicon|PAK}} [[Naveen Perwani]] 6–5 **men's semi finals: ***{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Daniel Ward (snooker player)|Daniel Ward]] def. {{flagicon|IND}} [[Manan Chandra]] 8–7 ***{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Kurt Maflin]] def. {{flagicon|THA}} [[Atthasit Mahitthi]] 8–4 **women's semi finals: ***{{flagicon|BEL}} [[Wendy Jans]] def. {{flagicon|NZL}} [[Ramona Belmont]] 4–0 ***{{flagicon|HKG}} [[In Wan-ip]] def. {{flagicon|IND}} [[Anuja Thakur]] 4–2 **women's final: ***{{flagicon|BEL}} [[Wendy Jans]] def. {{flagicon|HKG}} [[In Wan-ip]] 5–0 *[[Tennis]]: [[2006 Tennis Masters Cup]], [[Shanghai]]: **Red group: [[Roger Federer]] wins his second match again in 3 sets after he lost the first versus [[Andy Roddick]]: 4–6, 7–6, 6–4. [[Ivan Ljubičić]] kept his chances alive by beating [[David Nalbandian]] 5–7, 7–6, 7–5.
==13 November 2006 (Monday)== *[[Baseball]] **2006 [[MLB Rookie of the Year Award|Major League Baseball Rookie of the Year Awards]]: [[Detroit Tigers]] pitcher [[Justin Verlander]] easily wins the [[American League]] honors while [[Florida Marlins]] shortstop [[Hanley Ramírez]] edges [[Washington Nationals]] third baseman [[Ryan Zimmerman]] for the [[National League]] award by four points. *[[American Football]] **[[National Football League|NFL]] [[Monday Night Football]]: [[Carolina Panthers]] 23, [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] 10. The Panthers needed a late [[Jake Delhomme]] touchdown pass to [[Steve Smith (American football, born 1979)|Steve Smith]] as the Bucs began a string of three games in eleven days with a loss. *[[Olympic Games]] **San Francisco abandons its bid for the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] following the announcement that the [[San Francisco 49ers]] plan to leave [[Candlestick Park]] for a venue in [[Silicon Valley]], leaving only [[Chicago]] and Los Angeles (which hosted in [[1932 Summer Olympics|1932]] and [[1984 Summer Olympics|1984]]) as the two [[United States of America|US]] contenders. [http://msn.foxsports.com/olympics/story/6167568?CMP=OTC-K9B140813162&ATT=235 (Fox Sports)]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[[Association football|Football (soccer)]]: General news: **In the first managerial change of the [[2006–07 FA Premier League|Premiership]] in England, [[Iain Dowie]] was released as manager of bottom dwelling [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. **[[Attilio Tesser]] was also sacked after only winning four points out of eleven matches at [[Ascoli Calcio|Ascoli]]. He is immediately replaced by [[Nedo Sonetti]]. **Also [[Lierse SK|Lierse]] fired their manager. [[René Trost]] was only able to help his team win two points out of twelve matches. *[[Tennis]]: [[2006 Tennis Masters Cup]], [[Shanghai]]: **Golden group: [[James Blake (tennis)|James Blake]] upsets the number two seed [[Rafael Nadal]] in a 6–4, 7–6 win. [[Nikolay Davydenko]] wins his first match in three sets versus [[Tommy Robredo]]: 7–6, 3–6, 6–1.
==12 November 2006 (Sunday)== *[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]: **[[Asafa Powell]], who equalled the 100m world record twice in 2006 and won all six [[IAAF Golden League|Golden League]] meetings, is named [[IAAF Athlete of the Year]] in the men's category. [[Sanya Richards]] won the women's award for her achievements in this year. Richards broke [[Valerie Brisco-Hooks]]' 1984 US national record and also won all Golden League meetings at her distance, the 400m. *[[Auto racing]] **[[2006-07 A1 Grand Prix of Nations, Beijing, China]]: ***sprint race: (1) {{flagicon|NED}} [[Jeroen Bleekemolen]], (2) {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Salvador Durán]], (3) {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Enrico Toccacelo]] ***main race: (1) {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Enrico Toccacelo]], (2) {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Oliver Jarvis]], (3) {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Karl Reindler]] **[[2006 Chase for the NEXTEL Cup|Chase for the NEXTEL Cup]]: [[Checker Auto Parts 500]] in [[Phoenix International Raceway|Avondale, Arizona]] ***(1) [[Kevin Harvick]], (2) [[Jimmie Johnson]], (3) [[Denny Hamlin]]. Kevin Harvick takes the checkered flag, but Jimmie Johnson can finish 12th or better next week at Miami and win the title. *[[Baseball]]: **[[2006 Konami Cup Asia Series]] in Tokyo, Japan: Championship Game ***[[Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters]] {{flagicon|Japan}} 1–0 [[La New Bears]] {{flagicon|Taiwan}} – Japanese team wins Asian championship for the second year in a row. **[[2006 Intercontinental Cup]] in [[Taichung]], [[Taiwan]]: Fourth day of [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] play ***[[Korea national baseball team|South Korea]] {{flagicon|South Korea}} 7–9 [[Chinese Taipei baseball team|Chinese Taipei]]([[Taiwan]]) {{flagicon|Chinese Taipei}} (12 innings)Taiwan crushes four home runs including [[Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium]]'s first ever [[Grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]] in its first ever extra-inning game. ***[[Netherlands national baseball team|The Netherlands]] {{flagicon|Netherlands}} 0–3 [[Japan national baseball team|Japan]] {{flagicon|Japan}} Japan stays undefeated heading into the rest day ***[[Philippines national baseball team|The Philippines]] {{flagicon|Philippines}} 0–24 [[Cuba national baseball team|Cuba]] {{flagicon|Cuba}} (7 innings [[mercy rule]]) – 15-run first inning powers the Cubans ***[[Australia national baseball team|Australia]] {{flagicon|Australia}} 8–7 [[Italy national baseball team|Italy]] {{flagicon|Italy}} (13 innings) – Australia joins the Taiwanese and the Dutch at 2–2. *[[Beach soccer]]: [[FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup 2006]] finals: **Gold medal match: {{fb|Brazil}} 4–1
